—Is the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services aware of recent criticisms by the Auditor-General about the professionalism of officers of government departments in government purchasing? What measures is the Government taking to improve opportunities for Australian suppliers to obtain government business, and more generally to improve professionalism in government purchasing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Burns for this question because it raises some important issues that are under current examination. The Auditor-General expressed some concern about the way in which government purchasing is being undertaken within some departments. Given that the overall responsibility for purchasing guidelines, et cetera, lies within my department, it is a matter about which I and the department have had some concern. The department and I, together with my Parliamentary Secretary who is principally responsible in this area, Janice Crosio, are working to develop a response.

PARA.TAB: The Government accepts the need to continually improve and enhance the professionalism and effectiveness of government purchasing, as outlined in the Auditor-General's report, and has taken a number of measures in this area. I should say—and I will come back to this area—that, while the Auditor-General is correct in that we do need to improve our performance, we do not need to apologise for the quality of our performance; it is recognised fairly widely as being of high quality.

A major program of training for staff involved in purchasing and the development of a national competency based procurement curriculum has been announced by the Government. We will be launching this program here at Parliament House this week. The secretaries to Commonwealth departments and agency heads, together with a wide range of senior departmental managers, have been invited. At that time, I will be having some more to say about the importance of purchasing and the need to ensure the professionalism of government buyers. The Government has also announced increased Commonwealth funding for the Industrial Supplies Office and a requirement for agencies to develop agreements with the ISO about how they will use its services.

While emphasising the importance of responding to those valid criticisms by the Auditor-General, purchasing guidelines developed by Purchasing Australia have been recognised internationally as a significant step forward in improving the effectiveness of government purchasing. The general manager of the purchasing branch within the Department of Administrative Services has had correspondence with the Office of Management and Budget of the President of the United States, which states:

ANSWER.PARA: Your purchasing guidelines are universally seen here as a real improvement in communicating basic principles effectively.
It requests further sets of that documentation and continues:
This opportunity for us to change is welcome by many but a challenge to develop realistic alternatives. Your work is a model for what can be done with the right commitment.

This letter is signed by the Deputy Associate Administrator of the Office of Management and Budget. While there is more to do and while the Auditor-General's review is welcome and the response to it is appropriate, Australia does not have any cause to be apologetic about the skill and the appropriateness with which we conduct the purchasing function.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. According to the Pearce report, by mid-November the department had clearly decided that no deposit was required for satellite tenders and a document specifically saying so was already in intradepartmental circulation. As this was clearly contrary to the policy approach spelt out in the 10 October determination for MDS tenders which imposed a five per cent deposit requirement, how could this possibly have occurred?

—That matter has been addressed by the Pearce report as Senator Alston correctly stated. As Senator Alston will find when he reads the papers that will be tabled in Parliament as soon as possible this afternoon—he has already been provided with an advance copy of those papers, as has Senator Bourne—the single document referred to by Professor Pearce in his report is included, as one would expect it to be, in those documents that are relevant to the satellite process. I read it with great interest. As Professor Pearce has said, it is the only document in that mass of documentation with corrected notations and margin notes and so on that Senator Alston received, I think earlier today, that specifically mentions the fact that no deposit will be required.

PARA.TAB: However, the Pearce report does cover the deliberations that were held by those officers in relation to that issue where, as has already been revealed to the Senate, a deliberate decision was taken. The Pearce report—I think from memory it was paragraph 26 or 27—canvassed the principal reason for that, which was that the officers, when they had been told by the Attorney-General's Department that they could not apply those prequalification tests which they wanted to put on, referred to in that earlier advice tabled in the Senate as being `the department's preferred position', because in the view of the Attorney-General's Department that would conflict with what would be a price based system, they then sent the amended proposal off to the Attorney-General's Department, and had done so on the assumption that this would be given commercial scrutiny by the commercial law section of the Attorney-General's Department.

I described this in the debate on Thursday as being in my view the most serious omission highlighted by the Pearce report. As Professor Pearce said—in the paragraph I have just mentioned—that assumption was not well founded, and that indeed is the explanation. They did take a deliberate decision to place prequalification conditions on, which would have picked up these problems. The Attorney-General's Department advised them that they could not do it. They then removed those prequalification conditions and sent the matter to the Attorney-General's Department, assuming that it would be given commercial scrutiny—and that assumption was not based on good grounds. That has been laid out quite comprehensively in the Pearce report, and it is a matter that will be redressed in advice which I will provide to the Senate later this week on how these problems are going to be addressed in a way that will ensure they do not recur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Pearce report says that the origins of that critical document and its status are not entirely clear. Has the Minister been able to get to the bottom of that document and the context in which it originated and, in particular, are there any records of the meeting that was held in mid-November at which, presumably, all these matters were discussed? Were they brought to the Minister's attention or was he once again given the mushroom treatment?

—Senator Alston has obviously not bothered to read carefully the documents that I took the trouble to provide him with as soon as they were available. We did make some attempt yesterday to provide the documents to Senator Alston, but they certainly would have been provided to him no later than this morning. All those documents make clear what Professor Pearce has said—and there is not a satisfactory explanation for it; it is an error which will now have to be addressed. The only document which specifically addresses in a positive, assertive way that no deposit would be required is the document that Professor Pearce has referred to in his report. It is contained in that bundle of documents which Senator Alston has and which I will table later today. Professor Pearce has also made adverse critical comment on what he believes to be the less than satisfactory record of keeping notes on the actual meetings that took place. (Time expired)

—I direct my question to the Minister for Family Services and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Further to the Minister's report recently on the treatment of women by financial institutions, what further steps can she propose to improve services to women in banks?

—The question reminds the Senate of the report to which I drew attention a week and a half ago. That report found that about 82 per cent of women were dissatisfied with the service they were receiving from Australian financial institutions. The report made a number of suggestions to banks about how they should treat women customers. The advice boiled down to one simple rule: if you treat women with the equal seriousness and the responsibility that you treat other customers, women will be much more pleased and, indeed, will not take their business away from that institution or bank to somewhere else.

PARA.TAB: I have another suggestion for banks. Following up that report, I discovered that of the 13 largest banks in Australia only four have a woman on the board of directors. The Government has appointed women to the boards of the Commonwealth Bank and the Reserve Bank of Australia. There are literally hundreds of women with great riches of experience, with great talent, with economic skills and with more skills besides, particularly the capacity to know how women might prefer to be treated when they go into banks. I can certainly make many nominations, though I will not do that here. But if any banks should seek my advice or the advice of the Office of the Status of Women there are certainly extensive lists of women who are more than competent and more than capable to assist in this way.

I challenge the banks of Australia to take the opportunity when there is next a vacancy on the board to consider filling it with a woman. I assure them that, in meeting this challenge, not only will they be promoting equality but they will also be, according to the report and the evidence of that report, practising good commercial sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government. What is more important to this Government: honouring bad election promises, such as unaffordable income tax cuts, or doing something significant to reduce the Budget deficit? Can the Government possibly do both?

—I think I have said everything I can say on this particular subject. We have outlined and identified the kind of Budget strategy that we are presently embarked upon in order to achieve a particular result by 1995-96; to outline a medium term strategy for getting there in this year's 1993-94 Budget, and to produce a result this year that is roughly equivalent to that which we produced last year. We believe that all those objectives can be obtained in the course of this particular Budget. The precise means by which we get there will be made clear on Budget night and not before.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has told us all of that before. I asked him a question on a matter of principle. In the Government's scheme of things, what is more important: honouring election promises or doing something economically responsible?

—We are deeply committed to principle, as is notoriously the case. One of the reasons we are still here after 10 years is that we are perceived as such by the Australian people. That will remain the case in the future.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the Government's response to the verdict in the trial of Fretilin leader Xanana Gusmao? Was the trial conducted fairly and was Xanana given adequate opportunities to mount a defence?

—Xanana Gusmao was found guilty last Friday, 21 May, under article 106 of the Indonesian criminal code, of sedition and rebellion and, under the emergency law, of possession of firearms. He has been sentenced to life imprisonment. He was not charged under the anti-subversion law, which carried the death penalty and, although the firearms offence did carry that penalty, it was not sought by the prosecution. The length of the life sentence has not been specified, but it should not be assumed that it means for term of one's natural life. In other cases in Indonesia life imprisonment has meant around 15 to 20 years, although with crimes against the State there have been cases—it must be acknowledged—in which this has been exceeded.

PARA.TAB: Given Xanana's self-acknowledged role as the leader of the armed resistance in East Timor and the uncontested nature of the key elements of the evidence, it has to be said that that verdict was not surprising. In fact, when compared with the charges laid and the sentences handed down in trials of other so-called rebels in Indonesia, Xanana's sentence is in fact less severe. His defence lawyer, Sudjono, has now said that Xanana is not appealing the sentence but will be seeking presidential clemency.

I have already made clear on a number of occasions, and I do so again, my hope and the Australian Government's hope that the Indonesian authorities will see the handling of Xanana's case as an occasion for achieving longer term reconciliation in East Timor, including through such strategies as a major reduction in the military presence, a major economic development strategy, further recognition of East Timor's distinctive cultural identity and possibly some greater degree of autonomy. It would obviously be of great help in achieving that reconciliation if Xanana's sentence were to be substantially reduced by presidential clemency and we will be making that point in our further discussions with the Indonesian Government.

As to the conduct of the trial, while in terms of the standards that we and others would ideally like to see applied, there were a number of specific problems with the overall fairness of the trial. However, they should not be overstated. None of them was unique to the management of this case nor were they, in our judgment, so severe or so deep in nature as to have fundamentally impaired the process that is provided for under the Indonesian Criminal Procedures Code. Overall, court proceedings were open to diplomatic observers, to local and foreign media and to domestic and international human rights organisations, including Asia Watch, the ICJ and a UN observer. That was a welcome development.

However, it was regrettable that certain individual observers, including Australia's Rodney Lewis, were prevented from attending, effectively at all, and that no observers at all were admitted to the trial sessions on 12 and 17 May. It is also a matter for concern that Xanana was barred by court authorities from reading out in full his own prepared defence statement. The criminal code of Indonesia does provide for the accused to exercise the right of a full and final say and defence lawyer Sujono argued strongly that he should be allowed to read the full statement.

On the question of legal representation, it is not clear again that Xanana was given the lawyer of his choice, but it does seem at the same time generally accepted that defence lawyer Sudjono did make diligent and comprehensive efforts in mounting the defence case. He met Xanana five times before the trial began and had no difficulty of access to him during the trial.

Finally, on the question of his treatment during detention and trial, we have no information to suggest that he was ill-treated, and we have been closely following the case through our mission in Jakarta from the start, including through contact with a number of independent non-government organisations. I remain confident of the assurances given to me at the highest levels of the Indonesian Government that Xanana would not be ill-treated in detention. I have, however, instructed our embassy in Jakarta to raise with the Indonesian authorities the need for continuing regular access by the International Committee of the Red Cross to Xanana and to other detainees.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Does the Minister agree that the department's proposed satellite licence tender processes differed markedly from the approach preferred by Cabinet in that it did not contain a financial capability safeguard? Was the Minister aware of this difference when he signed the 19 January determination which did not require the payment of a deposit?
—These questions are canvassing issues which have already been gone over at length—
—Very lengthy!

—Indeed, ad nauseam, in the Senate. That matter has been specifically addressed again and again. The clue, as I said some weeks ago, is contained in the AG's advice that was tabled earlier in Parliament. Professor Pearce's report has now indicated that in terms of what I said was a clue was correct—that is, the line in the AG's report which says, `The department's preferred position is. . . ' and then goes on to list the very prequalification conditions that Senator Alston has just referred to. The department went ahead precisely in accordance with the Cabinet determination and drafted a set of five hurdles, one of which was that prequalification of company viability. The AG's advice was sent back to the department rejecting all of those five hurdles—not, as I took pains to say in here, rejecting the next possibility of putting a deposit on, but rejecting the very hurdles that Senator Alston has just referred to.

PARA.TAB: What then happened—I was correct, I have just looked it up; it is canvassed in paragraph 27 of Professor Pearce's report—is that, having had AG's advice, which has already been tabled in here, a fortnight ago, that this could not be done, the department then sent it off to AG's and assumed that commercial scrutiny would be given to the document by the commercial law section of what is now, I am told, called the Attorney-General's legal practice. That was not done. As I said in the Senate last week, and I am again going over this issue, I identified that as what I thought was probably the most serious single omission, as Senator Kernot and Senator Bourne will recall. In paragraph 27 Professor Pearce found that there were not sufficient grounds on which that assumption could be made. That was an error. I am now determined that procedures will be put in place that will ensure that the error will not occur again.

On the general question of ministerial responsibility that Senator Alston is canvassing once again, in one of the more thoughtful newspaper articles I have read about this last week, there was a reference to a research paper on this subject by Barbara Page of the University of Sydney. It is a fascinating article which canvasses all of the 11 occasions since the beginning of the Fraser Government when Ministers have been called upon to resign over departmental maladministration. One of the most fascinating involved Senator Durack who, of course, is still with us. Senator Durack's case was unique in that it was not just the Opposition which called for his resignation and the media which, as this paper points out, always call for Ministers to resign. That call for resignation in Senator Durack's case, as I am sure he will recall, was joined publicly by two very prominent colleagues of his who were former Ministers, one of whom is still in the House of Representatives, Mr Andrew Peacock. The interesting thing about this paper in terms of the wall-to-wall humbug which has been written on the subject is that none of those 11 Ministers resigned—not one of them—up to and including Senator Durack. For the edification of honourable senators who have got some interest in this matter, and it is an interesting paper to read, I table the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that by 19 January he had forgotten the express requirements imposed by the Cabinet? If he had not, why did he not take the matter back to Cabinet or at least alert his colleagues instead of simply doing nothing and leaving it all to his department?

—Once again, Senator Alston is simply going over, at tedious length, ground that has already been gone over. This has been explained to the Senate again and again and it is specifically contained in Professor Pearce's report. I would suggest to Senator Alston that he now do what he clearly did not do and had not done when he debated the matter on Thursday: read the report.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications—and it is not about pay TV. Would the Minister advise the Senate of Australian involvement in the development of new marine navigation systems which will benefit ships trading in Australian waters?
—This indeed is a very interesting issue.
—You always do this when he's in trouble. We have heard this three or four times previously!

—No, we have not as a matter of fact, Senator Macdonald. It may be of particular interest to senators from Victoria and Western Australia. For a number of years, the United States Government has been developing a new generation satellite navigation system designated as NAVSTAR global positioning system, or GPS. This system provides transmissions that can be used in civil applications with a specified position fixing accuracy of 100 metres.

—You would not need a satellite to track down Senator Walters; you could hear her from a bloody satellite. While this is sufficiently accurate for most marine situations, some applications, such as navigation in channels and confined waterways, would benefit from greater accuracy.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Maritime Safety Authority is examining the possible introduction into Australia of a new navigation service known as the differential global positioning system or DGPS. This new system will enable vessels to determine their position to an accuracy of better than 10 metres over a range of at least 200 kilometres from a DGPS facility.

The increased accuracy of the new system will be of particular benefit to hydrographic surveying and for the navigation by merchant vessels in confined waterways, channels and ports as well as for offshore recreational craft and the fishing industry. Of course the implication of this for environmental protection is obvious.

AMSA is undertaking an evaluation program of this new navigation system. As part of the evaluation program, AMSA will be installing DGPS facilities at Cape Schanck, near Melbourne in Victoria, and in the north-west of Western Australia. The two systems will initially be operated on a trial basis to evaluate their performance. The Victorian system will cover Port Phillip Bay, Western Port Bay and the Victorian coast. An assessment will be made of this coverage for the Tasmanian north coast. The Pilbara system will cover the approaches to three major ports in the region—Dampier, Port Hedland and Port Walcott. Transmissions are planned to begin in Victoria in December this year and in the Pilbara in March 1994. The system will transmit data in the medium frequency marine radio navigation band. To use the system, a vessel will need to fit a DGPS receiver to pass the data to a GPS receiver.

AMSA is examining the possibility of establishing a national network. There are many coastal areas which would benefit from the provision of the establishment of a national service such as—I am sure Senator Calvert would appreciate this—Tasmania and, of course, also the Torres Strait and the Great Barrier Reef where accurate vessel navigation on the inner reef route is critical. This is another important development in ship safety and I commend AMSA for its initiative in developing this.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to an incident that occurred at the Brisbane airport in July 1992 when an Ansett 727 blew an engine and was forced to return. During the emergency procedures, events took place that were reminiscent of the Keystone Cops. The senior operator control officer position had been abolished and no response was obtained at his phone. The metropolitan fire brigade dispatched two units to a locked gate and were denied access. Three airport fire brigades were dispatched from their holding point; one drove into a ditch and was rendered inoperative. The metropolitan police learned about the incident over the commercial radio and arrived 1 1/2 hours later. In view of the very serious nature of the lack of emergency procedures, can the Minister advise why there has been no surveillance by the CAA of the airport emergency plans? Will the Minister table all documents concerning this extremely serious matter?

—This issue was canvassed at some length during the estimates committee hearings, and I am sorry that Senator Boswell was not made aware of that. But the situation is that this incident, which was a serious one, has been fully—
—Very serious!

—All right, very serious. In fact, I was advised afterwards that Senator Herron was on board and, I am told, turned a whiter shade of pale, as I would have too. The important thing about this incident is that it was thoroughly investigated by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. That report has now been completed in its draft form and, in the usual way, is being exposed for comment to the agencies involved. It will be available in its completed form by the end of this month. —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications confirm whether his department gave assurances, written or verbal, to Northwest Airlines that the airline did not need to limit its Japan to Australia passenger numbers to less than 50 per cent of its capacity on its New York-Osaka-Sydney service? Was the Minister informed of such an undertaking? If so, when, and what action did he take?

—I have pursued this issue and I have been advised that the officer concerned is strenuously denying that such comfort was given or such statements were made. I have, of course, asked the officer to provide me with a written statement providing information. In fact, I checked this morning and I am told that that request is being complied with. The officer concerned has just come back, I am told, from Nairobi because of his new responsibilities in the Environmental Protection Agency, but I know he has vigorously denied it.

PARA.TAB: But I point out the obvious: even if it were true—and he asserts it is not true—clearly, in terms of relationships and agreements between countries, verbal assurances are not worth the paper they are not written on. It is simply ridiculous for anyone to assert that he or she could rely on some alleged comment made by some alleged departmental officer, who is now denying it, when addressing such a matter.

The fact of the matter is that this agreement was progressed between Australia and the United States. An agreement was reached that the primary aim of this service would, obviously, be the growth of United States-Australian traffic and that a target of 50 per cent of traffic from Japan to Australia, which our own carriers service, would not be exceeded. It is a fact, rightly or wrongly, that Northwest has not abided by that agreement—which it signed and which it gave an undertaking to abide by—in one single month since it has been operating the service.

I conclude by saying that the agreement provides for arbitration. The Australian Government is asking for the matter to be arbitrated. Indeed, we have appointed our arbitrator. The matter will be progressed in strict accordance with the terms of the air services agreement between ourselves and the United States. We all hope that it will be resolved quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the Minister's department has been acting without his being fully aware of all the issues in relation to the TV tendering process, can he assure the Senate that he has been fully briefed in this case? Will he table all documents, minutes, advices and other communications received by his department in relation to this matter?
—I have just given a very complete answer to the Senate about the Northwest airline dispute. There is a written agreement—

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct; it was a very full answer. The officer concerned has rebutted those assertions. I have asked him to put those rebuttals into a statement to me. I understand that that is now being done.

PARA.TAB: I will again point out the obvious; I cannot really add anything to my previous answer. We have a written agreement with Northwest, which it has signed, that it will abide by certain conditions, which it has not. TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services to an article in today's Australian Financial Review on fine art auctions by Sotheby's and Christie's. The press report states that articles which are claimed to be of little historical significance in Australia are being resold overseas at high prices to museums. It is claimed that Christie's in particular has a strong record of selling important objects from Australia into major collections. I ask the Minister what steps the Government has taken to see that these items are correctly valued and to ensure that the Protection of Moveable Cultural Heritage Act is not being deliberately flouted.

—The Protection of Moveable Cultural Heritage Act 1986 was enacted by the Government to prevent the removal of significant cultural items from Australia. I emphasise that it does not cover items which happen to be in Australia that somebody at an art auction might consider commercially valuable and which are measured—as in the very recent instance that provoked this article—by the preparedness of people to pay a lot of money for them, but that they are assessed to be of cultural significance to Australia. There are measures for dealing with that.

PARA.TAB: Owners of objects that are covered by part II of the Act must apply to the department for a permit if they wish to export them. The assessment is made on the cultural heritage significance of these items, not necessarily on their commercial value. The recent matter of controversy that provoked the article involved an historic calculator that was valued at a very low price but which was eventually sold at a very high price through Christie's. That might be a matter of concern to people who bid off the Christie's catalogue, but it is not necessarily a cause of significance to us, even though it is a matter for contemplation because the calculator was in the possession of an Australian. But that of itself does not make it of cultural significance in Australia.

Part VI of the list under that Act applies to objects of applied science and technology and the criteria that generally apply are that the object must have been either built in Australia before 1930 or in use in Australia before 1920. Those are the criteria against which these things are assessed. The calculator in question was brought to Australia after that time. There is no record of its having been associated with any significant Australian historical or scientific figure. It is not considered significant to the history or culture of Australia, although it is a significant item internationally.

We do not want to make it impossible for Australians to participate in the normal trade of internationally significant materials that are not of great cultural significance within Australia. Assessment of objects such as these covered by the Act are made by the National Cultural Heritage Committee, which provides me with recommendations on applications for permits to export such objects. As I said at the beginning, the purpose of the Act is to protect items of significance to Australia's cultural heritage, not to hold items in Australia simply for their commercial value.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Mr Keating stated during the election campaign that over the next four years $410 million would be recovered from doctors by investigations into Medicare fraud and overservicing. How will this be done?

—I have been talking to the HIC in the last couple of weeks as to how we will handle our efforts on fraud and overservicing over the next few years. As Senator Herron will recall, the Auditor-General has referred to the matter, although he did not seek to quantify the amounts concerned. These are targets which we have set ourselves in the estimates and which we hope we can reach.

PARA.TAB: In meeting with members of the AMA on Thursday night, I put to them that prior to embarking upon the program to get the $410 million, or indeed any part of it, we would like to involve them more in the process. That being the case, the HIC, my department and the AMA will be meeting in the course of the next few weeks to see how we might develop a strategy for giving more responsibility to the profession to aid us in making sure that we protect and make accountable every dollar that we spend on health care. That will be our aim.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Obviously the Minister is unaware that the Auditor-General did in fact quantify it and said that over the last four years only 27 doctors were successfully prosecuted and less than $4.5 million was recovered. It was quantified in the report and the Minister has not read it. Does the Minister therefore agree that Mr Keating's claim is another example of electioneering fraud and overservicing?

—I am amazed, given Senator Herron's particular knowledge in the area, that he does not know that Australia is currently making savings of $100 million a year from pathology alone as a result of the work we have put in over the last few years. He has to be joking if he thinks we cannot get more than $4.5 million. In any event, we are not talking only about fraud; we are talking about overservicing. There is a vast difference which apparently Senator Herron does not recognise.

—My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and relates to the trial and attitude of Xanana Gusmao. Does the Government have any further information on the whereabouts, condition and circumstances of Mr Gusmao's close friends and family members who were arrested and held by the Indonesian military soon after Mr Gusmao's capture?

—I have made known to the Indonesian Government Australia's concerns not only in relation to Xanana himself but to all detainees in East Timor, expressing my hope that they will be given legal representation, that they will not be ill treated and that the International Committee of the Red Cross, the ICRC, will be granted access. In addition to an ICRC visit to Xanana on 7 December last year, the ICRC has also visited a substantial number of detainees in East Timor with repeat visits to several of them. In addition, during his visit to Indonesia the UN special envoy to East Timor, Amos Wako, visited a number of detainees besides Xanana, including the former deputy Fretilin leader, Mauhudu; the purported successor to Xanana, Mauhunu; Xanana's sister and brother-in-law; and several other detainees.

PARA.TAB: I understand several of those detained in the wake of Xanana's arrest have now been released, at least temporarily, including Xanana's sister, Armandina Gusmao, and his brother-in-law. Armandina is quoted as saying that she is no longer in detention but under protective custody. —I address my question to the Minister for Family Services. The Minister would be aware of ongoing concerns expressed by the Family Planning Association and others about delayed processing of contraceptives which are readily available to women overseas. Can she report on procedures implemented by the section responsible for therapeutic goods administration to speed up approvals of contraceptive products?

—I thank Senator Reynolds for her question. In particular, I am able to advise the Senate that this morning at Symonston I had the pleasure of opening the new TGA—Therapeutic Goods Administration—building. That is a variously—depending on the figures—$61 million, $62 million or $63 million building. It was built on time and under budget. The facility brings together the TGA's administration and laboratories which were previously dispersed throughout Canberra and Melbourne. Indeed, the opening of the laboratories is the culmination of this Government's policy of revitalising the approval of therapeutic goods to ensure that Australians have timely access to the treatments they require.

PARA.TAB: The Government has been pursuing this objective, particularly the establishment of the laboratories, for some time. Indeed, I think the process of actually getting that building established is some 29 years. But, in fact, the design of the building started in 1987—the final commitment to proceed—and the construction in 1989. It matches very well the passage of the Therapeutic Goods Act, which was introduced and passed in this place in 1989, and that provides the legislative basis for a new uniform national system. The States are in the process of passing complementary legislation to ensure that therapeutic good products are all subject to proper regulation. The Government is not only concerned though with legislative or physical structures. In particular, we were concerned to look at how that process was delivered.

My predecessor, the hon. Peter Staples, commissioned ex-Senator Peter Baume to report on the effectiveness of the TGA. As a result of ex-Senator Peter Baume's report—and I might say, it is an excellent report—we now have a report of priorities and practices for the organisation that allows the TGA service to be completely revitalised.

That report principally goes to the timeliness of testing. There has to be a balance between being able to test the drugs in a reasonable time so that the advantages of the introduction of those drugs into the Australian market are permitted to the benefit of Australian citizens and, at the same time, ensuring that those drugs are adequately tested and are not released prior to their safety being guaranteed. We know that that is a fine balance, and I believe the recommendations contained in Peter Baume's report produce a very good outcome in terms of bringing those two factors together. In particular, not only is timeliness established but also it is encouraged by financial penalties.

It is proposed that the sponsoring organisation or people seeking permission for a drug or testing of a drug pay 75 per cent of the charge up front. If the TGA cannot deliver the testing in time, the last 25 per cent of the charge is not required to be paid. I have to say that since those changes have been introduced so far there have been no delays or late approvals.

I can assure the Senate that I will maintain a keen interest in the work of the TGA. In particular, I will be looking at ways in which the TGA can extend its export services to our region. It is important to recognise that the TGA not only delivers scientific data but also provides a very important service. I have also asked the TGA to look at ways in which it can actually encourage more girls and women into the field of science and into higher levels of the TGA. I will be pursuing this matter with my colleague Senator Schacht.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and relates to housing for service personnel and their families. Can the Minister advise whether the establishment of the Defence Housing Authority has led to any improvement in the quality of service accommodation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —The recent—

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This may not be of interest to Senator Newman. I suppose that it would not be of interest to people like Senator Newman who live in luxurious and palatial homes, but for many other ordinary Australians it is of a great deal of interest. The recent dramatic improvement in the quality of houses occupied by service personnel and their families is a very significant achievement of this Government. The Government has recognised that the need to have a mobile, responsive Defence Force places significant pressures on service families and that they do not need the added problem of inadequate housing.

PARA.TAB: So much has been achieved that it is easy to forget the magnitude of the defence housing problem of just a few years ago. At that time families were required to live in houses that were too small and that were in inconvenient locations. Provision for repairs and maintenance was inadequate and often long delays were suffered. Poor quality housing was impacting adversely on morale and wastage rates of skilled personnel.

In 1986 the Government decided to fix this problem and made a 10-year commitment to invest $750 million—in 1986 dollars—to improve the quality of defence housing. The Defence Housing Authority was established as a government business enterprise to manage housing on a commercial basis. Over its first five years of operation, the Defence Housing Authority has acquired more than 9,200 good quality houses. It has disposed of more than 8,000 of the worst of the houses considered below community standards. It has also increased the value of its housing assets from $520 million to $1,650 million. It has spent $217 million on repairs and maintenance and a further $103 million on improvements to existing houses.

The authority's policy has been to maximise the involvement of the private sector. An example is the housing estate at Wattle Grove in Sydney, which is a joint venture with Delfin Property Group Ltd. The Wattle Grove estate is an outstanding example of a development which integrates service personnel and their families into the community in good quality, well landscaped housing. Similar estates are being developed at Fairview Rise in Ipswich, Queensland, which I know is of interest to Senator Colston, and Streeton Views at McLeod near Melbourne under joint venture arrangements. Independent surveys of service families confirm high levels of satisfaction with the new houses acquired and the quality of repairs and maintenance service.

The Government's commitment to decent housing for our defence personnel and their families is showing dramatic results. These improvements in defence housing show that the defence organisation is a responsible employer. They are also a sign of the Government's progressive public sector housing policies.

The Cambodian people, who had already affirmed their faith in the peace plan by registering to vote in such enormous numbers, have now shown an overwhelming desire to exercise their right to vote to participate in the process.

PARA.TAB: I am able to inform the Senate that UNTAC estimates that about 45 per cent of eligible voters—that is, about 2.1 million people—went to the polls yesterday, the first day, despite heavy rain in some provinces and obvious concerns about what might happen at some of the booths. All the polling stations have been opened this morning, on the second day. There are long queues of voters and no major incidents have been reported so far.

I think this is a powerful and moving justification of the great international effort that has gone into bringing us to this point. I am very conscious that this week is not yet over and that many further difficulties may confront the remaining implementation of the settlement. But certainly the process is off to a good start, and I am sure that all honourable senators will share my pleasure that that is so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation relating to newspaper reports of my conversation with the Victorian Premier last week.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —A series of newspaper reports on Saturday, 22 May purport to report on a telephone conversation which I had with the Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett, on Thursday night, 20 May, concerning some potentially embarrassing difficulties that had arisen in relation to three Victorian police officers, who were fingerprint experts, going to Cambodia. Nearly every such report was coloured by extreme poetic licence, and that is to put it at its most charitable.

PARA.TAB: The Weekend Australian refers to my having a `heated' discussion, the Herald-Sun refers to me as being `angry', the Telegraph Mirror refers to a `row', and the Adelaide Advertiser refers to me as being `furious'. Not only are these descriptions utterly out of character; the truth of the matter is that all those accounts are a total fabrication. I was certainly bemused by the news, and I certainly did ring Mr Kennett on Thursday night to find out what happened and to see what might be done about it, but the tone of that conversation was perfectly amicable. As my press secretary was at pains to point out to anyone who asked—and a lot of people did—and as one would expect from fellow patrons, might I say, of the Hawthorn Football Club.
The matter was speedily fixed the next morning by the Premier reviewing the situation, as he promised he would. I rang to thank him on Friday and had yet another amicable conversation with him.

The press loves to colour these things; it loves to play with stereotypes. But that is no excuse for getting things just plain wrong. It does not help the conduct of either international or domestic intergovernmental relations when things are so blatantly wrong in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Kemp proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Labor Government came to office in 1983 we have witnessed a massive devaluation of the Australian dollar. Only one thing has been devalued more in this country than the value of our currency and that is the word of our Prime Minister (Mr Keating). As my colleague Senator Tierney said in his notice of motion, it is very clear that the Prime Minister went to an election making promises that he and his Ministers knew simply could not be kept. PARA.TAB: The Government's obvious intention to abandon its election promises in order to reduce the massive Budget deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: In just over two months Australian voters have seen the Government back away from, modify or substantially delay promises in a whole range of areas including the funding of its dental health program, providing a home child-care allowance, purchasing private hospital beds for public patients on hospital waiting lists, and funding a survey of the Darwin to Alice Springs railway—an issue of particular importance to my colleagues from South Australia, to which Senator Ferguson recently referred.

PARA.TAB: During the last election I debated retirement policy in the Ivanhoe Town Hall with the ALP member for Burke, Mr Neil O'Keefe, before some 500 pensioners and self-funded retirees. During this debate—I think this is important because it was witnessed by more than 500 people in the audience—Mr O'Keefe was asked whether the Keating Labor Government intended to keep its promise to exempt all age pensioners from tax by 1995. It was a very clear question and I was asked the same thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did he say?

—Senator Patterson will be appalled to learn that in answer to this question and in front of all these pensioners Mr O'Keefe promised that by 1995 all pensioners and part-pensioners, whether in receipt of some age pension or service pension, would be exempt from tax. That promise to pensioners was repeated all over the country. I believe Senator Patterson can quote a similar case in the electorate of Holt where the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, made precisely the same promise, and all of my colleagues can refer to similar examples. This promise was made deliberately to fool pensioners and part-pensioners—and it is just one of many. This was a major promise with significant implications for many older Australians which, along with the other promises I have listed, has been dumped by the Government.

PARA.TAB: Madam Acting Deputy President, you may recall the fanfare when the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, announced at the start of the election campaign on 19 February the basis of his new accord with the ACTU—accord mark 7. You may recall that the headlines on that day were all about a new pay deal with the union movement. A central part of the agreement was that after 1 July—in just over a month's time—there would be a $8 a week pay rise for all workers to provide a safety net for those who did not achieve pay rises through workplace bargaining. This was a clear election promise; it was made in the context of an election campaign. It was intended to show that this Government believed, through its economic policy, it could make this kind of guarantee to all workers.

But what happened? Just a few weeks ago—some two months after the election campaign—this commitment to all Australian workers was scrapped and its scrapping was announced by none other than Mr Martin Ferguson of the ACTU. So those lower paid workers, that core constituency of the Labor Party, have lost their pay rise. It is interesting to note that on 1 July, the date on which lower paid workers were to be entitled to their $8 a week pay rise, members of the Senior Executive Service, the highest paid members of the Public Service, including those on $100,000 plus per year—the Mr Costello's of Senator Evans's department—will become entitled to performance based pay rises.

On 1 July, ordinary workers will have to forgo their $8 per week pay rise. On 1 July, the Senior Executive Service will be entitled to performance based cash bonuses, ranging from $8,000 to $15,000, which will be payable after 1 July. I suggest to the Senate that Mr Keating made an interesting comment about the Government's priorities. Mr Keating had no problem in keeping his promises to higher paid workers—a promise which was endorsed by Mr Kelty and Mr Ferguson of the ACTU—but his commitment to lower paid workers was not kept. In fact, it was scrapped.

This is only the start. What we are seeing is a Budget deficit out of control; a Budget deficit of Whitlamesque proportions. Those of us who lived through the appalling mismanagement of the Whitlam period from 1972-75, and Senator Sherry will recall this period, are now seeing the same thing emerging with Mr Keating. This is a result of the irresponsible nature of the commitments he has made and because he will do and say anything in an attempt to win an election.

This year's Budget was originally forecast to have a deficit of $13 billion—this is a figure that Senator Sherry will certainly confirm. This Budget has already blown out by some $3 billion and will probably show a deficit in the order of $16 billion.

When we examine next year's Budget we find that the deficit will continue to spiral. The so-called starting point for next year's Budget—I think as Senator Evans or certainly his colleagues have confirmed—will be in the order of $18 billion. Mr Keating is the highest taxing, highest spending Prime Minister in Australian history. He is far worse than the notorious Mr Gough Whitlam.

As a result of the spiralling Budget deficit, a Budget out of control, it is clear that Mr Keating will have to dump another series of promises, including the major election promise not to raise taxes. We can recall, and I am sure Labor senators will recall, that this Government has a magnificent record of breaking its central election promises.

What was the central election promise of this Government in 1987? I am sure honourable senators will remember. It was that by 1990 no child would live in poverty. That was a promise made by Mr Hawke and endorsed by Mr Keating, even though he knew it could not be kept and even though the finance Ministers and senior Ministers of this Government knew it could not be kept. That promise was of course broken.

What was the central promise of the 1990 election? I remind Senator Sherry that the central promise was that there would be no recession. Day after day during the election campaign, Mr Keating went around informing the electorate that there would be no recession. What happened? We had the worst recession in 60 years and a million people unemployed.

What was the central promise made by Mr Keating during the 1993 election? I suggest to the Senate that the central election promise was that there would be significant income tax cuts and no consumption taxes of any sort. Those were the promises that Mr Keating made when he went into the last election. It has become clear from the figures that I have quoted that taxes are going to have to rise, and will probably have to rise very substantially indeed. Mr Keating made these promises knowing full well that if he was elected the day of reckoning would come, but that when he was safely ensconced in the Lodge, with perhaps two to three years to govern the country, all the commitments that he made to Australian voters could be dropped. In my view, those promises will be dropped.

In just two months the Government has moved from its position of promising `no new taxes' and substantial income tax cuts to the position of floating a whole series of new ideas on future tax increases. One example has been the foreshadowing of a rise in the excise on fuel taxes. Perhaps Senator Sherry could confirm whether the Government will proceed with its proposal for an excise tax on energy—presumably on coal and natural gas. Ideas have been floated—

TALK.START.PARA: —I can't answer questions.

—When Senator Sherry gets up to speak in this debate he will have the opportunity to tell us the answer to that question and to make an ironclad commitment that the Prime Minister's promises will be kept. I remind Senator Sherry that we will want to hear from him that the income tax cuts that were promised will remain in place and that there will be no new consumption taxes. Every word that he says will be listened to by honourable senators in this chamber and by people listening to the radio to hear whether he is prepared to make that commitment. I suggest that if he makes that commitment then his life as a Parliamentary Secretary might be somewhat attenuated.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Left has floated the idea of a new wealth tax. Even the inimitable President of the ACTU, Mr Martin Ferguson, who wiped out wage increases for ordinary workers, has urged the raising of income taxes on the higher income-earning groups. Of course, it did not worry Mr Ferguson that the higher paid levels of the Public Service were provided with cash bonuses. Articles in today's edition of the Sydney Morning Herald and other newspapers announce that a range of new taxes and charges to be imposed on government services has been floated.

Almost every day the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) stands up in this Parliament and, through her questioning, urges the Government to break its promise to cut the level of income tax. Honourable senators will recall that the Democrats used to be the party whose role, as it was often expressed in this chamber, was to `keep the bastards honest'. Surely one aspect of keeping them honest would be to ensure that they kept their promises. I would have thought that was one element of keeping people honest. If a party goes into an election campaign promising to significantly cut the level of income tax, surely the Australian Democrats would see their role as ensuring that such a promise was kept. We have seen nothing of the sort. In fact, Senator Kernot has marked her accession to the leadership of the Australian Democrats by demanding that the Government break its central election promise to cut income taxes—a funny start for the leader of any political party, particularly one that markets itself as the party that will keep the major political parties honest.

Make no mistake about it, the Government will renege on its tax promises. Of course, the Government has a way out of its dilemma: to start pruning government spending. Honourable senators will recall that in Fightback the coalition identified areas where significant reductions in spending could be achieved. The Commonwealth Budget now totals almost $110 billion and is growing at a very rapid rate. Since 1989-90 Commonwealth Government spending has increased in the order of 16 per cent in real terms—a very substantial increase—while Public Service employment has increased by almost eight per cent, which is also a very sharp rise. Those two areas must be financed by either taxation or borrowings, and in most cases both.

As I said before, we have found out that not all people will suffer from broken promises; the higher paid public servants will get their promise of substantial cash bonuses. I suggest that all those who are in the welfare area—on a number of occasions Senator Patterson has referred to the problems that voluntary groups in the welfare area have in providing emergency relief—might recall that the cash bonuses that the Government has promised to those senior public servants who receive an income which sometimes stretches over $100,000 will cost the Budget at least $40 million. Those welfare agencies may well reflect on the priorities of Mr Keating.

As I have said, Mr Keating has promised new benefits for pensioners, substantial income tax cuts for all but the very lowest income earners, wage increases for all workers, new child-care provisions for young parents and further help for welfare agencies. All these promises are now in the process of being thrown out the window.

One area of particular interest to me is the Government's promise that corporate taxes would be cut to 33 per cent. It has to be admitted that this is a significant cut. This cut is to be funded by bringing forward tax payments from companies. In 1996-97 the cost to revenue of the company tax cuts equals about $1.7 billion. Senator Sherry will confirm that the additions to revenue from bringing forward corporate tax payments will also be about $1.7 billion. The problem is that after 1996-97, the bringing forward of the corporate tax payments washes out of the system and the Government will be left, in a comparatively short period, with yet another black hole in the Budget stretching towards $2 billion. This is why I say that the irresponsibility of this Government in the last election campaign will be demonstrated in the coming months.

I say to people who are listening that, if they received a promise from any Labor government member or Minister, now is the time for them to write to the Prime Minister and remind him of that promise. Now is the time for them to write to all Labor senators and members and remind them of the promises that they made, not only the specific promises they made to their group but also that they promised major income tax cuts and no new consumption taxes. I suggest to those who are listening that time is running short and now is the time to tell their Labor members of parliament what they think about governments that lie to the Australian people.

The rules of this Parliament prevent me from calling Mr Keating a liar and a cheat, yet outside this Parliament these are the very words that the Australian electors are using when they refer to the man who would say anything in order to cheat his way into high office.

—They will learn.

—Senator Kemp can laugh, but if I were sitting on his side of the House, I would not be laughing; I would be crying into that glass. The Opposition finds itself in an unfortunate position. Every year at Budget time there is, as I said earlier, wild speculation which is pointless and counterproductive. We could add up the hundreds of wild assertions that the Opposition makes. TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance being discussed here this afternoon is the Government's obvious intention to abandon its election promises in order to reduce the massive Budget deficit. With the Opposition, the Australian Democrats agree that the Government has already started to renege on some of its promises, but we actually think it should on one of them—and I will get to that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: The commitment to take all pensioners out of the tax system by 1995 and the proposal to establish a national investment council proposal have already been abandoned by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). The rescheduling of the start-up date for the extension of Medicare into dentistry has been delayed and the introduction of the home child-care allowance has been indefinitely delayed. These are but a few of the promises which honourable senators have already outlined this afternoon. Unfortunately, this reneging on promises appears not to be applicable to the one initiative which we think should be axed, and that is the planned personal income tax cuts. They are irresponsible and unaffordable and so many people in Australia know that.

These tax cuts will deliver about nothing to almost half of the population; that is the rub. People earning $20,700 or less will get nothing from those cuts. But they will provide a tax cut of almost $50 a week for people like us earning $50,000 a year or more. That is a disgrace. It is absolutely the wrong targeting. It is an extravagant and totally political measure. It was introduced by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, perhaps to win the election, although I am not convinced that Australians are so easily bribed. I think Mr Keating thought he was going to bind a future conservative government to $8 billion worth of expenditure which it may or may not have wanted. Whatever the reason, these tax cuts should now be axed.

I am proud to say that when we look at the consistency stakes in this matter the only people with the real form are the Democrats. We said we could not afford the tax cuts; we still say we cannot afford them. We say that Mr Keating should do something in the national interest and abandon them, and we will help him, tomorrow if necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep them honest and break the promise.

—Yes, Senator Kemp, it is a matter of weighing up what is in the national interest and what was a shocking election promise. But what did the Opposition say? It said, `Shock, horror; this is a terrible thing. We cannot afford them. But, guess what, we will vote for them because previously we used to believe that governments have a right to implement their own economic agenda'.

PARA.TAB: Suddenly we have the shadow finance Minister, Mr Peter Costello, and the shadow Treasurer, Mr Alexander Downer, saying, `We will adopt this new strategy of no new taxes'. It seems to have been largely overlooked at this point in time by both the press and the Opposition but, as I understand it, it is still binding on the parliamentary party.

It is also noteworthy that the Opposition's pledge is quite narrow in practice because, when the original threat was made, it would have encompassed matters other than those which will be in the Budget. I ask whether Senator Kemp acknowledges that there are currently two new taxes before the Senate. One is a specific levy to fund the clean-up of maritime oil disasters—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a tax.
—I said `taxes' in inverted commas. The other is a levy to fund some of the activities of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Will the Opposition be opposing these?
—That is a user-pays charge.
—Oh, are user-pays taxes okay?
—You supported it.

—I do. Shadow Treasurer Mr Alexander Downer was questioned on that topic on the Sunday program yesterday. His response was that the Government does not have a mandate to broaden the existing sales tax, nor to increase the existing rate of sales tax. However, he said that the Government was under an obligation to meet its election promises, including its legislated income tax cuts. When specifically asked whether the Opposition would support the repealing of the income tax cuts, Mr Downer rejected this option, which means that the only option the Opposition supports to control the deficit is the cutting of government spending. I think one could argue that the Australian public voted against this aspect of Opposition policy because it was a major part of the Fightback package as well.

PARA.TAB: Ironically, this Government has actually announced a `no new spending' policy. It is apparently looking to cut about $2 billion off expenditure this year to reduce the bottom line of the Budget from $18 billion to $16 billion. In the absence of massive economic growth—say, growth rates above five per cent—additional revenue measures will be needed to meet the deficit target of about $5 billion by 1996-97.

As is always the case, the Democrats will await the detail of any alleged changes to sales tax before we decide whether to support or oppose them. However, there is no validity whatsoever in the shadow Treasurer's contention that the income tax cuts should be honoured. As Mr Laurie Oakes pointed out yesterday, the Opposition now appears hell-bent on trying to force the Government to honour promises which the Opposition has quite rightly criticised as unaffordable and irresponsible in the past. If a measure is against the national interest, then it should not be proceeded with, irrespective of whether it was an election promise or not. Indeed, as we all know, that promise should never have been made in the first place.

So we reject the approach of the Opposition on the tax cuts, and I call on the Government again to remove what in fact amounts to a ridiculous and self-imposed straitjacket on itself. Abandoning the tax cuts would make the deficit targets more easily achievable without having to impose regressive increases in indirect taxes. I do agree that the Government, after having argued so strenuously against a change in the tax mix from direct to indirect taxation in the election campaign, has achieved nothing but a mandate not to embark upon such a switch. In addition, it certainly does not have a mandate to radically slash spending. Something has to give in this equation and the something is the tax cuts.

I have already predicted—Senator Gareth Evans has attempted to deny it but we will wait and see—that the first round of tax cuts, with a little bit of swift footwork, could be deferred by the Government until 1 January 1996, thereby giving Mr Keating the opportunity to offer to the electorate the ultimate bribe just before the 1996 poll. However, the problem with that is that while it might meet some electoral objective it does not solve the problem of the long-term budgetary cost. Given that the tax cuts will be adding about $8 billion a year extra to the deficit by 1996-97 and the cut in the company tax rate will add an extra $1.8 billion to the deficit in 1997-98 and beyond, the goal which the Government says it is pursuing of meaningful deficit reduction is impossible to achieve without large increases in taxation.

The Government won the election by a clever, but largely false, scare campaign against the GST. Although the GST would have been regressive, there would have been compensation by way of both personal income tax cuts and increases in pensions and benefits.

Ironically, the Government's proposals are much more regressive. There is no income tax cut for those Australians earning under $20,700. There will be no pension and benefit compensation for price increases occasioned by an increase in sales tax, although the normal mechanisms for increasing pensions and benefits will apply. Those earning under $20,700 will be adversely hit without compensation—and this from a Labor government.

The Government's obvious revenue options have already been canvassed in the public debate. These are: increasing the categories of goods which are subject to sales tax; increasing the rate of sales tax on goods which are currently being taxed; imposing a tax on some services; imposing a new tax or increasing existing taxes on energy; and increasing dividends from government business enterprises. All of these will be regressive in their impact, although their precise nature cannot be estimated until the detail is known. But we cannot say, as the Opposition does, `In ever raising the idea of a new tax, you could not possibly be addressing any other public policy goal'. For goodness sake, that is out of the question for the Opposition.

Other options could be included: abandoning the income tax cuts, as I said; reversing the company tax rate; increasing the income tax paid by higher income earners; repealing the imputation credit system, which will reintroduce the classical company tax model and would raise many billions of dollars; imposing some withholding tax on franked dividends; and a domestic withholding tax on interest, as floated last year, to stop people not declaring interest earned. I make no comment on these options but merely point them out for discussion.

Senator Kemp will undoubtedly jump up and say, `This is what the Democrats propose. This is what the Democrats raise for public discussion'. I have already told Senator Kemp that we wait to see the colour, the detail, of the legislation. It has also been reported that a lot more specific measures might be introduced to attach specific fees to a whole range of services. We have seen this in recent years in such areas as passport, other immigration levies and bonds—

TALK.START.PARA: —Superannuation.

—And superannuation. These can be expected, irrespective of the state of the Budget deficit, although they may be accelerated somewhat. All taxation measures should be judged against the criteria of equity, economic efficiency and sustainability.

PARA.TAB: There is no general answer to the Opposition's threat because the Democrats will continue to judge all proposals on their merits. As Senator Kemp knows, we have a consistent history of that, way back to opposing taxes on the necessities of life. The Opposition is now shifting philosophy midstream and asking Australians to swallow it. Our commitment has not wavered.

What about reducing revenue? One area where this is a distinct possibility is savings. We have an unprecedented situation where the Government, I think, has lost control of the savings issue. In a typical Canberra ploy, the Government has just commissioned Mr Vince Fitzgerald to look yet again at providing some policy options on the national failure of savings in this country. We know what they are. Some of us have been talking about them for years.

I do not know what recommendations Mr Fitzgerald will make, but it would probably be safe to guess that they will not include an increase in the taxation on savings. Indeed, on the contrary, the recommendations will probably go in the other direction, which will impose a further burden on the Budget.

The more pressing area in this whole debate is effectively dealing with high levels of unemployment. That will take a lot of thought, a lot of action and probably a lot of money—an option which the Opposition seems to have effectively locked out at the moment. This problem should be accorded much higher priority than an election bribe which has no community support.

The Democrats support the matter of public importance before the chamber today, although, unlike the Opposition, we actually wish the Government to abandon its most irresponsible and unaffordable promise. SPEECH.PARA: The Treasury, Department of Finance and Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet are concurrently drawing up a list of other areas for review—

—a process of which portfolio ministers are aware. . .

SPEECH.PARA: The arbitrated—

There are three essential steps involved in accessing the arbitrated safety net . . .

The union/employers may after a reasonable period seek to vary the award by increasing the award rates. This claim shall be limited to $8.00 subject to the overriding conditions of the Accord.
The overriding conditions of the accord are set out in the introduction. I do not want to keep reading; I will just read the introduction, paragraph 1.1:

This three year Accord agreement has been formulated to address the key social concern facing Australia today—unemployment. It is an agreement based on cooperation not conflict.

SPEECH.PARA: Union commitments have been an essential underpinning to the wage system and will continue to be so. The union movement will honour the undertakings outlined in this Accord agreement, including the following specific commitments:

PARA.TAB: (i) all claims will be assessed against employment growth.

I will illustrate some of the things the Government is doing with industry policy which, I think, is the key to furthering development and further reducing unemployment, which is so necessary. This is a further significant incremental measure in this Government's process of encouraging industry. That process has been going on for 10 years.

SPEECH.PARA: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 5) 1992-1993

Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1992-93, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 6) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), which I shall introduce shortly, comprise the Additional Estimates for 1992-93.

In these Bills, Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made for 1992-93 under Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1, 2, 3 and 4) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act.

The additional appropriations in these three Additional Estimates Bills total $1,681.3 million; $1,257.7 million is sought in Appropriation Bill (No. 5), $418.4 million in Appropriation Bill (No. 6) and $5.2 million in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2).

These amounts are offset, in part, by savings in the Appropriations made by Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1, 2, 3 and 4) 1992-93, reflecting the Government's determination to improve the efficiency of continuing programs, as well as changed funding arrangements for the Australian National University, the Australian Maritime College and the University of Canberra. These institutions have been funded from a special appropriation from 1 January 1993, as agreed by Parliament in the last session.

The savings in the appropriations, amounting to $595.4 million in gross terms, are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document "Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations", which has been distributed to Honourable Members. After discounting those savings by the amount of $119.6 million attributable to the changed funding arrangements I have just mentioned, the net prospective savings identified by departments against the annual appropriations are $475.8 million.

After allowing for net prospective savings, the appropriations sought represent a net increase of $1,205.5 million in appropriations for 1992-93, an increase of 3.2 per cent on the amounts made available at the time of the 1992-93 Budget.

I turn now to the main areas for which the Government has found it necessary to seek additional provisions in the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1992-93 to meet payments for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

Although the Budget figuring made allowance for prospective wage and salary increases, that amount was not then appropriated. Funds are now required to meet increases resulting from award decisions. $288.9 million is included in Appropriation Bill (No. 5) for increased running costs for all departments and agencies including Defence; an increase of 2.7 per cent on the funding for running costs included in Appropriation Act (No. 1). This amount includes the costs associated with agreed wage and salary increases, transfers between financial years and some additional funding for departments associated with various government initiatives which have been previously announced.
Gross additional estimates of $836.3 million are sought for the Defence Portfolio in Appropriation Bill (No. 5). This figure includes:

$390.3 million for Australian Defence Industries (ADI), principally associated with a $390 million purchase of equity in ADI as part of a debt for equity swap. That payment will be offset by a payment from ADI to the Commonwealth;

$257.1 million for Defence Housing which includes provision for a $191.3 million payment to the Defence Housing Authority (DHA) as part of a debt for equity swap. The payment to the DHA will be offset by an equivalent payment from the DHA to the Commonwealth;
$115.0 million for Running Costs principally due to the effects of the award increases and provision for redundancies included in the amount of $288.9 million I have already mentioned; and
$50.3 million for stores and equipment which largely reflects adjustments for price movements and exchange rate variations.
In addition, Appropriation Bill (No. 5) includes provision for:

$34.0 million for the Department of Employment, Education and Training for Running Costs associated with the CES network workload formula, as well as Government initiatives in respect of the implementation of the Mayer Report and the employer incentive scheme;
$14.6 million for emergency relief reflecting the dollar for dollar matching of funds raised by charities in their Christmas appeals;
$30.3 million for child care fee relief which reflects growth in average fee relief and in the number of private sector places;
$17.2 million for matching of rates for Medical Officers and nurses in Repatriation Hospitals with relevant State rates; and

$20.4 million for payments to the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, largely reflecting the effective writeoff of Russian wheat debt and losses associated with the writeoff of the rescheduled Egypt wheat debt resulting from a factoring transaction.
The balance of $131.0 million in the amount included in Appropriation Bill (No. 5) is made up of minor variations across a range of programs across most departments and agencies.

These additional appropriations are required to meet the 1992-93 commitments that have been made by the Government since the Budget as well as unavoidable cost and price increases and other parameter changes since the Budget was prepared.

The Bill also includes a clause for the creation of a provision for Running Costs borrowings. This provision will be limited to $20.0 million and will be used to provide flexibility for Departments and agencies to fully utilise the Running Costs Arrangements. Reports will be provided to the Parliament on the use of the provision.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1993-94

This Bill, together with its companion Bills, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1993-94 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1993-94, is a routine machinery measure. It seeks interim appropriations for the ongoing services of the Government during the period to 30 November 1993, by which date it is expected that the Appropriation Bills, which form part of the Budget for 1993-94, will have been enacted.

Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $13,347.5 million for the ordinary annual services of the government. This is $965.0 million, or about 7.8 per cent, greater than the equivalent amounts provided in the Supply Act (No. 1) 1992-93.
