It will be used to provide flexibility for Departments and agencies to fully utilise the Running Costs Arrangements. Reports will be provided to the Parliament on the use of the provision.

I wish to emphasise that this bill seeks interim provision only for approved ongoing policies of the government. It does not anticipate decisions to be taken in the 1993-94 Budget context, for which provision will be sought in the Appropriation Bills.

The object of supply is to ensure that finance is available for the ongoing services of government until the next appropriation should be made as part of the 1993 Budget. In the Budget last year it was estimated that the deficit—that is, the shortfall in this financial year—would be around $13.4 billion. In February of this year that was revised downwards and the current estimate is that in this financial year the Commonwealth will come in with a deficit of almost $16 billion—up more than almost $3 billion from that estimated in last year's Budget. This means that every day of this financial year, 1992-93, the Commonwealth Government will be overspending by about $43 million more than it raises in its revenue. I ask honourable senators to consider that.

But it does not stop there. In absolute terms, the projected Budget deficit of $15.9 billion is the highest ever in the Commonwealth account and there are now suggestions that the deficit will blow out to some $18 billion. That is almost $5 billion more than what was estimated this time last year. I think that, in a very few words, that clearly shows the incompetence of this Government and the Labor Party when it comes to dealing with money. We have seen Labor Party governments in Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania simply unable to handle money and, each day that goes by, the evidence shows that this Labor Party Federal Government is incapable of handling the hard-earned money of the Australian people.

When the current Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, became Minister for Finance back in March of 1990, he had a surplus of $8 billion. Not only has he now cut back that surplus, but he has also gone into a deficit of about $16 billion and possibly higher. So in a three-year period, this Minister has turned that surplus into a deficit of historic proportions: an overall turnaround of some $33 billion. That is a record for any finance Minister in our Parliament.

Mr Deputy President, you and the public know that, if a company director oversaw such a turnaround in company profits, then that company director would be sacked or otherwise would somehow find his way to Majorca. But this Minister for Finance, who presided over that enormous turnaround in the Commonwealth Budget, gets rewarded: he is reappointed as Minister for Finance, holds his position and carries on with business as normal. How can any decent Minister continue to remain in office without doing the right thing: accepting responsibility and resigning? As I say, in the private sector, that sort of person would end up disgraced and even worse.

The latest funny money scheme the Government is talking about is having pay TV licences for the ordinary public; it hopes to get some money from that. It reminds one of the days of Whitlam, Khemlani and Rex Connor. More and more, Mr Keating is looking like a Gough Whitlam—head in the clouds, full of hot air and surrounded by incompetent Ministers—as the economic rug is slowly pulled from beneath him.

We have run this terrible Budget deficit in the context of the highest unemployment rate in Australian history. There are officially one million unemployed. Madam Acting Deputy President, you know, as do Senator Sherry and I, that the figure is more like two million. There are 700,000 children growing up in families where no-one works. No redeeming benefits whatsoever can be pointed to to justify this terrible situation.

I am appointing a new member to my staff. I had the sad task—it was one of the most difficult things I have done for a long time—of trying to respond to the 80 or 90 applications made for the job, which is fairly low paying by Public Service standards. Those kids were desperate for the job. Many of them had one or two honours degrees covering a wide range of subjects. They are very skilled kids yet they are currently employed as shop assistants at Venture, caretakers and gardeners. Most of them are unemployed. It is an absolute tragedy and it is brought about by the mismanagement of the Labor Party.

Mr Beazley today said that the number of long-term unemployed will rise to half a million and that it will fall at the end of the century to `notionally acceptable levels'. I just wonder what he means by notionally acceptable levels. I am sure the long-term unemployed who fit into that category will be comforted by the fact that their number has been cut by 10 or perhaps 20 per cent! It is an absolute disgrace that this Government should accept a long-term unemployed figure of 500,000 that it can do nothing about.

What distresses me also about this matter is that this Government makes such a great deal of publicity about these things that it has desensitised the Australian public into believing that unemployment will be there and always should be there. It should not be there. If Australia could get going, as it would have done had the policies that we proposed at the last election been adopted, we would not have had to accept as normal—would not have had to become desensitised to—those huge numbers of unemployed and the huge foreign debt which this Government has no inkling at all how to deal with. The Government's dishonesty in dealing with the economy is matched only by its dishonesty in its election campaigns and before.

Time does not permit me to go through these at any length but I know that many of my colleagues will highlight them during the debate. It seems fairly clear that the Government will embark upon its own GST through the expanded sales tax program. Most of the sensible newspaper columnists are now writing about that. An energy tax has been floated and even a water tax. When she was well away from the spotlights during the election campaign, Mrs Kelly said that she thought water was too cheap. Can honourable senators believe that! We can be assured there will be some tax on water shortly, and we will get back to death duties before very long, or we will have the Langmore solution of trying to rob the rich to give money to the growing army of unemployed.

We find ourselves in a disgraceful situation. The lies and deceptions which this Government uses to win elections just go on and on. The record of financial mismanagement is evidenced in these Bills. These are money Bills, and the Liberal and National parties will not oppose their passage because they are necessary to keep the Government going. However, we do propose an amendment to the second reading. I move:
At end of motion, add: ", but the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)notes the dramatic deterioration in the budget position estimated in the August Budget as a $13.4 billion deficit and subsequently revised to a $15.9 billion deficit;
(b)notes the fact that in the last 3 years there has been an effective fiscal deterioration of $33 billion;
(c)notes the Government is pledged to introduce no new taxes, but has no strategy to reduce the budget deficit by reducing outlays; and
(d)condemns the Government for its failure of economic management".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Macdonald on Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1992-93, Supply Bill (No. 1) 1993-94, Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), Appropriation Bill (No. 6), Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1993-94 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1993-94. As it generally does at this time of the year when it has a Budget blow-out, the Government is seeking an additional appropriation because of supposedly unforseen circumstances. May I say, before Senator Spindler leaves the chamber, that it is peculiar that there is no Democrat listed on the speakers list on such important Bills. I do believe that the sole purpose of the Australian Democrats in this place is to let the Government carry on doing exactly what it likes.

PARA.TAB: The Government is seeking an additional allocation of $1.3 billion due to an approximate Budget blow-out of $2 billion. Whereas we had an expected Budget deficit of about $14 billion, this additional allocation will take that deficit to about $16 billion. In the last couple of days, Senator Evans has admitted that the Budget deficit will be $18 billion, which is a national record and a national disgrace.

The Government could have foreseen this situation in last year's Budget and could have done a lot of things to have reined in that deficit. Now, as stated of late in the press, all the Government has done is defer any assault on the deficit to try to keep some faith with the Australian population—a population which the Government fooled during the election with promises that it has either put on hold or has totally gone back upon.

I will list some of the broken promises of this Government. The promise of tax relief for pensioners was excluded even before the election was over. Labor's commitment of removing all age pensioners from the tax system by 1995 was to benefit pensioners paid at the part rate as well as to provide some assistance to retirees with incomes beyond the pension cut-off point. That promise, which was in the Government's 1993 policy document for older Australians, has been forgotten altogether.
Senator Richardson put the dental health program on hold for six months the other day when he said in a radio interview on 19 May:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . From my predecessor's office there came a release some time later which did include a reference to emergency procedures starting on the first of July.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating had this to say on 24 February 1993 about the promise to introduce a child care allowance:

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise and appreciate the important role played by women who choose to stay at home.
I totally agree that it is an important role. He then said:
We propose to introduce a new cash payment of $60 each fortnight to be called the Home Child Care Allowance.

After reading the fine print, I can remember immediately raising the point with the media, in an attempt to get it to run with this, that the dependent spouse rebate would go out the window. I made this point by way of interjection in the first Question Time following the policy announcement, and one Minister said that it was irrelevant and had nothing to do with the situation. However, those two decisions just happened to be implemented at the same time.

PARA.TAB: I heard on the radio this morning evidence to suggest that the media has finally recognised that the spouse rebate will go out the window. The home child-care allowance simply changes that rebate into extra income for the husband. If the husband is working and the wife stays at home, the allowance would come out of his pocket and go to the wife. I suppose that is fair and rational thinking, but why did the Government not tell us that at the time?

From my knowledge—forgive me if I am an odd dollar or a few cents out—the spouse rebate for an employee with a dependent wife and two children is in the vicinity of $47 a week. In other words, according to my calculations, $47.11 is deducted from a PAYE employee's tax contributions every week. The Government has said that the rebate for the child allowance will be $30. Where has the other $17 gone? My suggestion is that that $17 would go towards the cost of extra administration.

The $47, or whatever the figure turns out to be—it varies slightly for people living in remote areas, but it is between $40 and $47—is simply deducted from the husband's PAYE tax and he takes it home. No doubt he hands it over to the wife just as, in most cases, he hands over all his income, because virtually the whole pay packet is needed to keep the home going if there is a wife and two dependent children. That would be a very efficient way of doing it.

No doubt the Government wants to play social engineering. It wants to take money off the husband and pay it to the wife. In the event that this measure ever comes into being, the wife would only get $30; $17 would be missing. I wonder whether someone can tell me, if and when this measure ever comes to pass, where that $17 will go. I am very annoyed that, during the election campaign, members of the press did not pick up this issue, because it was pointed out to them and they did not do anything about it.

Another promise was the improvement of Medicare through the use of private beds. What has happened to that proposal? I will not say what the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) had to say about that proposal. Various other promises have been made.
Another promise involved providing $3 million in funding to survey the 300-kilometre Darwin to Alice Springs railway link. That is a good one. Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: The next Labor Government is happy to fund the remaining surveying so the commercial viability of future proposals can be more accurately ascertained.
Where has that promise gone? It has been postponed or forgotten already.

PARA.TAB: I will tell the Senate the coalition's position in the federal election campaign regarding the Alice Springs to Darwin railway line. The Darwin to Alice Springs railway line will only be built under a coalition government through its joining with private enterprise in utilising many of the resources that are still untapped between Darwin and Alice Springs. Private enterprise would be asked to come aboard once the railway was up and running. A coalition government would then step out and leave it to be run totally by private enterprise.

In Question Time today Senator Ferguson said that it was a very necessary project in order to link the south with the north and use Darwin as an access port to Asia. Rail would then be used to freight goods to Darwin, which would lessen the impact on the roads. I will get back to roads later on. The Government has made various other promises but has done very little about them.

I turn now to another aspect contained in the appropriations or statements made by this Government as we move towards the next Budget. I will refer briefly to what the Industry Commission had to say about road transport in Australia from the late 1970s until the present day. The Industry Commission referred to the application of the neo-classical economic theories of the 1980s. Unfortunately for the Australian population, this Government has been in power throughout most of the 1980s. Anyone trying to run a business and develop new projects will know that the Government has produced negligible benefits for road transport.

The Industry Commission said that new ideas and actions are urgently needed to put the sector on an internationally competitive basis. It was the view of the Industry Commission that the only thing that had happened in that time was the reform of user charges. That is all that has been done. There has been a reform of multiple user charges, which has increased the taxes on road transport. However, these have not been reflected into road funding.

The Industry Commission went on to say that road investment levels in Australia have only been targeted for increases when spending has been needed to boost the economy and not as part of a general theory of economic growth. In other words, during any lead-up to an election or when the economy is bottoming out—although it is actually still in a free-fall—this Government simply makes certain announcements about what it will do with regard to road funding. This is vastly different from the approach of our Asian competitors in trade where infrastructure spending on roads is part of each country's economic structure and can be generated at all times.

Overall spending in Australia has decreased. It has not increased since the mid-1970s, but in real terms it has decreased since the Fraser years. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry), who is at the table, is looking at me in amazement, but if he reads up on this matter he will find out. Since 1970 we have gone backwards in spending in real terms, but there has been a 180 per cent increase in car travel and a 320 per cent increase in truck travel. Yet this Government has not given roads the priority that is needed for Australia to keep up with other Western countries. Most Western countries have a continuous and ongoing commitment to roads, but Australia has not.

It is time that Australia did the same as these other countries. Road agencies should receive these road user charges and apportion them in a non-political way. In other words, whatever money is available should be apportioned to areas where it will improve the road system and reflect what is needed in project and resource development. The money should be apportioned into that sort of development rather than being spent on black spot programs designed to relieve unemployment. It so happens that those black spot programs were implemented in marginal seats, as in the case of Stirling which the Government ended up losing anyway.

I would have liked to see the Government address those points. But so far it has failed to address them and I believe it will fail to address them in the Budget also. In my own State of Western Australia, for instance, a vast injection of capital is needed on the main railway line which stretches from Perth to Sydney. I know that the Government made some money available in the One Nation package for re-sleepering and upgrading, I think in Queensland, Victoria and parts of Western Australia. But we have not yet seen that money.

One section between Kwinana and Koolyanobbing needs a lot of upgrading. The Western Australian Government was promised that funding quite some time ago, but as yet it has not come through. Koolyanobbing was an iron ore town which closed down in 1983, but fortunately is now up and running again. The line from Koolyanobbing out to the Port of Esperance also has to be done up. It could be made much more efficient than the Kwinana line, but no funding is available.

They are the sorts of things that the Government should be addressing. It should be getting projects going which will do something towards reducing the figure of one million unemployed. The Government is now starting to accept the fact that Australia will have those unemployed forever and a day—or at least for the rest of the decade. That is contrary to the Government's promise made during the election campaign that it would reduce unemployment and whatever else.

I believe this Government got back in by fooling the population at large. Madam Acting Deputy President, I have already shown you how this Government fooled the women of Australia in the previous election campaign; I have already done that with the issue of child care, which Senator Sherry and the Cabinet have immediately put off. Government senators have the hide to come in here and say that, because of unforseen circumstances—which they have known of all along—they have had to go back on that promise.

The Government has fooled the women of Australia and it has fooled a lot of others too. It fooled people about the company tax collections which supposedly reduced company tax from 39c to 33c. I could see through that measure at the time and Senator Watson probably saw through it before I did. We got onto the press, but they would not run the story. The Government fooled the people about that issue. It will be collecting more money in taxation rather than less. The Government has failed us. It has failed us by going back on its promises and now it is casting around for what to do.

The coalition did not win the last election because of the untruths which were put around by the Labor Party, the Labor Government and the unions. We were hurt by these untruths on four fronts: firstly, the GST; secondly, education; thirdly, Medicare; and fourthly, the Kennett factor. On all of those issues we are proving that our policies were right. Day by day, government Ministers are admitting our policies were correct because they are getting closer and closer to our point of view. All of our policies were right; this Government misinterpreted them and the press helped the Government. The Australian Democrats laid down for the Government. Where is the Democrat speaker on these appropriations?

—Yes, he was nowhere to be found. Where are they now to come in and question the Government? They are not coming in. They all helped to put the Government back. Now the Government is casting around—
—I do not think they were ever here in the first place.
—Senator Sherry can have his go a bit later.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans said in reply to a question today that the GST was definitely a non-goer and was rejected by the people of Australia. But I know that the Treasury of Australia has been working on an expanded and supposedly streamlined new sales tax system, and it is in this article. The system has been around for two years and the Government is looking at the idea of making three levels of sales tax only that would average out at 15 per cent and not take away the taxes that we were going to take away—fuel excise and all of those excises—to help the businesses of Australia and the export industries. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I compliment my colleague Senator Panizza on the very important matters that he has raised tonight. In my comments tonight on these Appropriation and Supply Bills, I want to deal with just one particular aspect which came out of the additional estimates the other night as a result of my questioning. It relates to the lack of coordination within the various arms of government, particularly in the Department of Trade, Austrade, which is tied to it, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. In doing that, while I will not go over all the debate that occurred, I wish to quote a number of statements which highlight very much the point that I wish to make. My question to the Minister at the time, Senator Gareth Evans, was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: You have led me to my next question, Minister. I make particular reference to the current wool crisis. What coordination is there between the Department of Trade, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Wool Realisation Commission in terms of identification of potential markets and alternative uses for wool?
Senator Evans said:

I think that question is better answered in the context of the inquiry that is now proceeding about how we might best take advantage of market conditions, getting rid of the stockpile and generally moving the industry forward. I suppose someone here might be in a position to give a snapshot account of how these arrangements have worked in the past.

I think that answer from the responsible Minister—in this case Senator Evans—highlights very clearly just how little coordination there is, how little he knew about what was going on and how poorly this Government had addressed the current crisis in the wool industry. Senator Evans then referred the matter to the officer at the table Mr Delofski. Mr Delofski said:
I am not aware that we are closely involved in the issue that you have identified . . .

I find that quite remarkable coming from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade which has, as we know, units all around the world in various countries. Of course, the answers were very similar when I questioned Austrade officers, although they had a little more knowledge of the matter that I was questioning them on, and the answers were not very different when it came to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

PARA.TAB: The reason I raise this is that it is now almost three years since the severe wool crisis hit Australia. Its impact is felt throughout the economy, whether it be on the producers on the ground, the service people or on the capacity of the industry to earn export dollars. This country has operated for three years in a total void with regard to a management plan for handling the stockpile. I want to quote from what I said in a debate in this place on 18 October 1990. It was at a time when people on this side of the chamber were saying that to get on top of the problems of a collapsed reserve price and a stockpile in excess of four billion bales a major effort had to be made to get a balance between supply and demand. I am sure that Senator Sherry would remember what I said:

In addition to the already announced low value slaughter scheme to humanely slaughter old sheep at an estimated cost of up to a $2 a head, a commercial scheme to slaughter the younger sheep must be considered. I would just like to say that unfortunately, in my view, the industry has no choice but to put in place a commercial slaughter scheme. In other words, I am saying that in terms of the situation now with the oversupply of wool the industry is at D-day and it is absolutely essential that the numbers be got down to around 130 million so that we have some chance of equating production with demand.
Unfortunately, and as unpalatable and difficult as it is, I cannot see any other way. If this action is not taken, the stockpile will become an albatross

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise that—

around the neck of the industry and more and more producers will be bankrupted as the tax goes up. This is not a debate about the floor price or the Corporation's existence or non-existence. Regardless of the floor price or the role of the Corporation, supply has to be reduced to demand.
On 15 November I said a very similar thing:

PARA.TAB: The position is totally unsustainable and it cannot go on. The stockpile has become an albatross which unless brought under control will destroy the industry in two ways: firstly, by distortion of market prices into the future and, secondly, in that the tax required to maintain it will send producers broke.

SPEECH.PARA: We have now had almost three years of crisis and this Government has no plan to manage, properly and sustainably, the Australian wool industry or to overcome its current problems. It is about time—to put it quite frankly—that government members got off their butts, put together a comprehensive plan, coordinated the various arms of government, did the research required and set up an environment where private enterprise would feel comfortable about coming back into the Australian wool scene, purchasing our wool as it used to be purchased and developing new markets. I could criticise the Government all night—that is very easy to do—and it deserves to be criticised, because, as I have said, it has had almost three years to address this problem.

PARA.TAB: The reason I spent a significant amount of Additional Estimates time the other night was to try to ascertain whether the various departments or arms of government, in conjunction with the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian Wool Corporation, which are also set up under statutes of parliament, were doing anything that was at all imaginative or likely to develop in the future. An announcement has been made with regard to the Garnaut report. We had the Vines report. We have had a number of reports into the wool industry and none of them has addressed the essential point—none of them has looked at how we are going to manage the wool industry through this difficult period, with supply still running where it is and the stockpile overhanging the market. As I predicted two and a half years ago, the stockpile has become an albatross around the industry's neck.

The proposition that I wish to put before this Parliament and the Government and will be putting before the Garnaut committee—in fact, I have even started processing the finer detail—is that a highly refined technical unit should be set up between the Department of Trade, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, Austrade, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, the Australian Wool Corporation and, I suggest, two professional, highly motivated marketers. This unit should have the responsibility of analysing and objectively researching various opportunistic markets, if I can put it that way, for alternative uses of wool.

We have heard many people throwing around ideas such that we ought to hand the stockpile to the CWA and get it all knitted into socks. We have heard other suggestions that a large percentage of the stockpile should be used for insulation. We have heard that barter schemes should be set up between what was formerly the USSR and other countries in the world. But these things have just been put on the table. None of them has been followed through. They need to be tested to see whether they have a place in the market. We then need to find people in private enterprise, whether it be within Australia or externally, to look at the total proposition.

I am putting before this Parliament and the Garnaut committee that we need to use the best brains in these departments and a couple of marketers and resource them properly so that they can carry out international research. I received a phone call about 10 days ago from some people from India who happened to be in Western Australia. They said that there was an opportunity in northern India, Pakistan and Bangladesh for wool to be used as insulation. They asked where they could go to find out how they could progress this idea. If we had a finely tuned, developed research unit that knew what it would cost to do these things and that could go into these areas and find out what was required and what the market potential was, it might give us a chance to do something constructive about the problem.

One thing I know is that we cannot continue to sit back in Australia and hope that somebody will come along with a big golden egg and solve the problem for us, because it will not happen; it is as simple as that. We cannot sit back in Australia and wait for this Government to solve the problem. It has to be driven into doing it. It is absolutely crucial that we in this place drive the Government. I have heard comments that some of these ideas that have been put forward are snake oil remedies. I agree that some may be snake oil remedies, but it does not necessarily mean that they all are or that they cannot be utilised somewhere.

The point that always comes to mind when it comes to the utilisation of significant levels of wool from the stockpile, even to pick up the additional production that exists in Australia, is that of insulation. A small company operating in Perth is insulating houses using a different process from the batt processes. It is cheaper; better in quality; safer from the fire aspect; and protected from infestation of bugs and wogs. That process has been neatly developed.

Until the Government actually gives somebody the resources, responsibility, direction and the guidelines and gets people who have a bit of will, get up and go and guts, we will just sit back and watch the wool industry wallow in the bottom of the trough, as it is doing now. I will have my critics in the wool industry because I have dared suggest we should walk through the golden gates of the Wool Corporation. But the structure of the Australian Wool Corporation is just so cumbersome and weighed down in its various aspects that it is not actually addressing the key point of finding markets. It is not finding alternative markets, researching those markets, measuring their size and potential, and then coordinating with private enterprise to bring about the development of those markets. I seek leave to table the extract from Focus on Wool, volume 2, No. 3, July 1992, headed `New structure of Australia's wool industry'.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not suggesting that the Government should actually be the processor or the manufacturer of the wool, but there is a role for it, when coordinated properly, in bringing about some of these things through its various arms. These arms of government could combine with a couple of dynamic people in private enterprise who are skilled in marketing—which would make a total of about seven people. It would be necessary to make sure that they had a very defined research unit and marketing promotional unit. It would be absolutely crucial that this body be resourced properly and thoroughly.

PARA.TAB: Estimates have been made of the additional income tax this Government received because of the operation of the reserve price scheme while the four million or so bales were stored. After the $1.8 billion of growers' money in reserve was spent, another $2.3 billion to $2.5 billion in funds was borrowed which was used to buy our wool, put it into the stockpile and increase the price. In my estimation, the additional income tax received by the Government was in the order of $750 million. It would not seem unreasonable to me, in view of the benefits that the Government and the community received from the wool reserve price scheme through additional income tax, that such a body could be resourced. I would give it a life of three to five years, with something like $50 million, so that it could get out there and tie it up. There would be no need for this body to set up new office structures because we already have offices established around the world, through our various embassies and trade divisions.

I have spent virtually all of my time in this appropriations debate speaking on one thing: the wool industry. I have thought a lot about something progressive, active and dynamic that will actually address the issue and not let it sit around as it has done for almost the last three years.

I would like somebody to come up with a better idea or a better way of doing this. I have not heard anything yet, but I do know that if Australians, this Government and this Senate value rural Australia—if they value the foundations upon which the wealth of this nation was built, the people who live in rural Australia and the multiplier effect of the jobs that come out of rural Australia—they will look very seriously at what I have put before them tonight. If we do not address this issue we will see the worst infrastructure collapse in this country since European settlement.

The wool industry today—and I must declare my interest in this area because I am a woolgrower—is in a very serious state. In fact, `serious' is not a strong enough word. Last year the wool industry, in the depths of despair, still put $3.8 billion into the Australian economy. If it is not worth having a close look—and I mean a close look—and actually taking up some of these issues and doing something about them, then it is not worth continuing to live in this country. I challenge the Government here tonight to look very seriously at what I have put before it and, after 2 1/2 to three years, not to sit around and wait any longer. The people out there cannot afford it and they deserve better treatment.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the appropriation Bills cognately. The Opposition has moved a second reading amendment to the Bills.

PARA.TAB: The Budget deficit has increased dramatically in the last three years. The Government was re-elected on 13 March after making many promises. One side of politics told the truth, told the Australian people what was required. Unfortunately, we did not win the election. I concede that point. We have a deceitful Government led by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating. How he can lie straight in bed, I would not know. He told so many lies during the election campaign—I had better retract the word `lies', because it is unparliamentary; I will use `untruths'.

Australia has a gross foreign debt of some $203 billion. Not enough store was made of this by the Government at the time of the election. Not enough store was made of the fact that the Government has a domestic Budget deficit that is burgeoning. It is of the order of $16 billion. That is a lot of money. It is very hard for many of us to comprehend what $1 billion is, let alone $16 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eight years of Australia's annual gold production.

—I thank Senator Panizza. That was very eloquently put. Senator Panizza, being from Western Australia, obviously knows a lot about what this Government has done to the gold industry. PARA.TAB: I believe the Government has to be held accountable. This level of imports is the highest ever recorded. Surely the Prime Minister should be coming clean with the Australian people and telling them exactly how things are instead of failing to tell them the full truth of the situation. We have got a spiralling current account deficit problem and a foreign debt which is increasing rapidly. What is this Government doing about it? It has said, `Okay. We have made some promises. We are going to break a few of those. We tell the truth always. We told the Australian people during the election campaign that we were going to do things, but already we are going to break some of those promises'.

I suggest that a couple of those broken promises might nearly have won the election for the Government; for example, the promise of the Government to match dollar for dollar donations to charities. I quote from the Prime Minister's media release of 6 December 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to announce today that the Government will match dollar for dollar cash donations by the Australian public to major voluntary agencies for their Christmas appeals.

The Government has decided not to match the amount raised through the Christmas appeals but only the money actually spent over Christmas. I believe that that promise would have won quite a few votes. I do not want to use unparliamentary words, but the Keating Government has welshed on the deal. Another promise that the Government made was that:
. . . a new Commonwealth dental health program will be established for emergency and basic dental care for health card holders.
The Government welshed on that deal—it pulled the plug. It was another promise broken. What do Australians expect from this Government?

PARA.TAB: Another broken promise was funding for the Darwin to Alice Springs rail link survey. Now that the election is over the Government is unable to give any time frame in upholding its commitment to provide funding for that survey. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether the Government is now welshing on that deal made during the election campaign.

The Government is now talking about raising taxes. During the election campaign it knew the state of the coffers. If it did not know the state of the coffers, then it should be indicted for a felony—killing the Australian economy by not knowing what it was all about. Surely the Government should have told the Australian people like it was. If it did not know the position and it is now saying, `We have to change it and we can't give some of the things we promised', then it has told an untruth and is indictable for the fact that it did not know the facts. Yet the Government has been in charge of those Treasury benches for quite some time.

The Government has got no mandate to raise taxes. It is now talking about broadening the wholesale tax range. That has increased from about $3 billion to about $10 billion under this Government which sits here and says, `The goods and services tax is no good for you. But we'll increase the wholesale tax take by some $6 billion'—another raking off from the Australian people of $6 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break I was talking about the broken promises of the Keating Labor Government. Until a second ago I thought I had blown senators on the Government front bench out of the water, or that they were not game to come back into this chamber because of their worry, concern and disgust that they had broken so many election promises—matching donations to charities, free dental care for pensioners and funding for the Darwin-Alice Springs rail link survey. But I notice that the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) has come into the chamber; it is great to see someone back on the Government side after the dinner break.

PARA.TAB: The Australian economy is in great disarray. We have a Government that is ripping taxes off us like we have never seen before. In fact, government revenue from primary industry charges has increased by 340 per cent since this Government came to power. In the same period, primary industry levies have increased by 72 per cent; the primary industry sector is being slugged all ways.

A Bureau of Industry Economics study has revealed that port authority charges in Australia are twice as high as comparable overseas ports. It is interesting that, recently, when Senator Collins was asked a question about this, he said that great reforms had been made on the waterfront. But I noticed in the papers in the last couple of days that the Minister for Trade, Senator Cook, who is actually doing a great job in this portfolio—trade is one of those areas of bipartisan support where we must be all helping each other to do the right thing for Australia—said that port charges are one of the problems as far as exports are concerned.

If one looks at some of those charges, it is little wonder. In one instance port charges for coal were up to 20 times higher in Australia than the lowest overseas charge. That is quite horrendous when one thinks about it. Looking at the wheat industry, for example, the world best was Vancouver at 16c, and Australian charges ranged from $1.11 at Fremantle to $2.63 at Wallaroo in South Australia. This made Australian charges at the waterfront seven to 16 times higher than those in other parts of the world.

As Senator Crane said earlier tonight and as Senator Panizza, on behalf of the farmers of Australia, said, how in the hell are we going to compete with the rest of world if we have charges like that imposed upon us? Why does this Government not do something about fixing up this problem in one way or another? To say that there has been an improvement, as Senator Collins says, is absolutely ridiculous. There has been improvement in Australian conditions; but, improvement compared to the rest of the world, not on your life. In fact, we are well behind the rest of world. It is time this Government woke up to it and did something about it to make sure that Australia becomes competitive.

Another interesting statistic is the $9.4 billion collected every year in sales tax, which I mentioned before dinner. That has trebled in the last nine years. The wholesale sales tax take by this Government has trebled in the last nine to 10 years. This Government, the Government that told so many untruths during the election campaign—it is now reneging on a lot of the promises it made—about how bad the goods and services tax would be for Australia, has a secret tax which it has never told the Australian public about, the wholesale sales tax regime, which has trebled in the last 10 years.

We should look at what this Government, the Keating Labor Government—because Mr Keating was the Treasurer before he stole the position of Prime Minister—has done as far as fuel taxes are concerned. Fuel tax costs the motorist $7.2 billion each year. In 1983 the petrol excise was a bit over 6c a litre. It is now 26.2c a litre. That represents tax by stealth. Again, the Government is not telling the truth to the Australian people; it is taxing them by stealth. When one thinks about the promises that this Government made during the last election campaign, who would ever trust it again? If we look at what our dollar could do for us in 1950 compared to what it does now we see that in 1950 3.7 bales of wool bought a standard Holden motor car; in April 1993 it takes 54 bales of wool to buy a standard Holden motor car.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's getting to be more.

—That is right; it is absolutely horrific. If we look at today's figures, perhaps even more bales would be required. In the last 10 years the Keating Labor Government's total tax collection has more than doubled. In 1982 the Commonwealth's total tax take was $40.8 billion, in 1992-93 it is predicted that the tax take will be $90 billion.

PARA.TAB: We are seeing government by stealth. The Government is ripping the dough off honest taxpayers, trebling wholesale sales taxes, and more than doubling the ordinary tax collection. Yet the Government got away with it on 13 March; it got away with telling untruths to the community.

Last week we were talking in this place about the wool industry, to which matter Senator Crane has alluded again tonight. Currently, there is something like 3.9 million bales of wool in the stockpile. In real terms, wool values are lower than they have been for 50 years. Only four years ago the wool industry earned something like $6 billion in exports; now it earns only $3 billion. ABARE predicts that this year the average woolgrower will lose just under $40,000 per year. That means that in the last three years the income of woolgrowers has halved. In total, each woolgrower has lost in excess of $100,000 in three years. Farm costs rose again in the March quarter—the biggest increase in two years. In fact, over the last 10 years there has been a 342 per cent increase in farm costs. Increasing costs are driving the nail into the coffin of the rural producers of Australia.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) gave some form of relief through his drought package and wool package. While those packages represent a step in the right direction, it is too small a step taken a little too late to really do the job for the people in the wool industry and the people who have suffered from the effects of drought in the last little while. Woolgrowers need a return to prosperity if Australia is to prosper in the future.

At the present time farmers are paying something like $1 billion in taxes on farm inputs. Yet we have a Government which, since the last election, has been talking of increasing taxes rather than dropping them, as it promised in its election campaign. Only last month the Australian Industrial Relations Commission granted a 2.5 per cent pay rise to shearers, adding another burden to the budget of woolgrowers which they can ill-afford to pay at this stage. In fact, they simply cannot afford a pay increase on top of all the other problems that they have.

This Government has to stop taxing our productive sectors, stop taxing transport and stop taxing production. Farmers simply cannot absorb any more tax increases while this rural crisis exists. Something also has to be done about the stockpile and the Government has to give incentives by way of guarantees of money so that we can get rid of some of that stockpile to some of the central European countries which need long term credit. Interest free loans have to be given to make sure that we can move some of our wool into the CIS—particularly Russia—and get rid of it. We have to be trading as a country to get ourselves out of this mess.

The bottom line is that when this Government makes promises and does not come up with the goods, and reneges on the promises it has already made—in other words, tells untruths to the Australian people—it is time it took note of the fact that it is our exports that will get us out of the hole. I call on the Government to do something about that—to take the taxes off our backs and make sure that we get our exports going again. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to what Senator Brownhill said about some of the troubles and trials that much of Australia's rural community is going through. I can only endorse the comments that he has made, particularly regarding the wool industry. Senator Brownhill has been in this place for a considerable time; when it comes to highlighting the problems and issues in rural Australia today, nobody knows the situation

SPEECH.PARA: better than Senator Brownhill. I commend him on his speech.

PARA.TAB: I would like to raise a couple of matters which were raised in the Senate today and which have received some media attention, but I believe not nearly enough. They are certainly far removed from the rural field. When they become common knowledge they will cause unrest, dissatisfaction and division in an area where Australia needs to be stable and united—that is, our defence forces.

We have heard a lot of talk today about enterprise bargaining and performance based pay rises. Performance based pay is the method by which senior public servants can be judged as to whether they have done a good job and awarded bonus payments. A debate is being conducted at the moment about performance based pay in the Public Service and I do not particularly wish to become involved in that. However, I do wish to state that I believe performance based pay does not necessarily belong in the military or in our defence forces—precisely because it will not promote stability and unity.

The idea of having senior officers at the same rank but earning different pay goes against the military ethos of `one company' and it will have a negative effect on morale. Even if this were not the case, how could performance based pay possibly be consistent across our three armed forces? How could we possibly compare a commanding officer of an operational squadron of fighter planes, who is an experienced pilot, with an army officer who is in charge of an intelligence section and an expert in Asian languages? How could we even judge within the services? How could we compare that same commanding officer of an operational squadron of fighter planes with the commanding officer of a base squadron in charge of financial and administrative matters?

But this is not the only reason why junior officers and other ranks are becoming increasingly angry about some senior officers getting pay rises. They are angry because there is no corresponding pay increase for them. The only thing that they will be getting in July is a decrease in the subsidy for renting married quarters. Their service allowance, which is paid in lieu of overtime and other benefits, has not changed since 1987.

It is hardly surprising that last week newspapers across Australia carried headlines such as `Armed Forces Uproar on Pay', `Performance Wage Bid Splits the Military', `Pay Deal Splits Ranks in Forces' and `Services Rift as Officer Pay Deal Riles the Rank and File'. This uproar, as the Age termed it, is easy to understand when we look at the issue for what it really is. Senior officers are agreeing to significant pay rises for themselves while junior officers and rank and file either do not get anything at all or effectively suffer a pay cut.

For all these reasons the Army has decided that it will not go ahead with performance based pay. Why? Because the Army consulted relatively widely and discovered that giving a hefty pay rise to senior officers, at the same time as many junior officers and soldiers would effectively receive a pay cut, would be very unpopular. The service allowance for junior officers and other ranks, which is supposed to be reviewed every two years, has not been increased since 1987. This allowance compensates for the loss of civil liberties, hours of duty and for forced moves.

Part of the rationale for the service allowance is, therefore, to be a payment in lieu of overtime and penalty payments, call-out allowances and many other payments that people in both the public and private sector regard as their legal right, and in many cases can be worth thousands of dollars each year. Yet Defence Force personnel, many of whom regularly spend weeks and months overseas and interstate, working irregular and long hours, receive only $4,000 a year to compensate for overtime as well as their loss of civil liberties, forced moves and many other features of Defence Force life which distinguish it from all other areas of work.

I would suggest that the Australian taxpayer is getting a real bargain. I certainly know of defence personnel who spend a significant amount of time overseas—usually working outside normal hours. Their overtime would easily exceed the $4,000 a year allowance which, of course, means that they are not being compensated for being subject to military discipline, for being posted every three years, or for the disruption that it causes to their families.

Paying defence personnel an allowance in lieu of overtime makes very good sense. If we paid flight crews overtime every time they flew early in the morning or late at night, or every time they were called out at 2 o'clock in the morning for a search and rescue mission, we would see an enormous hole in our defence budget when it comes to the salaries of defence personnel. This allowance has been stuck at $4,000 since 1987 when it only increased by one-third of the expected amount. The Australian Armed Forces Federation estimates that for the service allowance to be brought back to its pre-1987 levels it would need to at least double to $8,000.

But this is a mere patch on the increases that some senior officers could receive under performance based pay. The top bonus that is being talked about is in the vicinity of $12,000 to $16,000 a year—an amount that really would not be very far off the lowest wages that are currently being paid in the Defence Force. Where is the equality in senior officers receiving bonuses almost equal to what their apprentices earn in a year? Some defence personnel receive the family allowance supplement because their wages are so low.

I concede that it is very difficult to make comparisons with defence pay and conditions, but I would like to know whether any other Commonwealth employees have effectively had their overtime frozen since 1987. Would the public sector unions which represent the public servants accept that a payment in lieu of overtime had not been increased for five years? I think not.
It is significant to note that in the published reasons for decision, matter No. 14 of 1992, the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the question of the review of Service Allowance has been before the Tribunal for some time and we consider that any further postponement of the review of the allowance would not be appropriate. Service Allowance is an integral part of the remuneration of ADF members . . .
It is no wonder that junior officers and the rank and file are angry. It is no wonder that the Army rejected the idea of performance based pay for senior officers.

PARA.TAB: There is an argument that Defence Force personnel should receive roughly comparable pay to that of personnel in the Australian Public Service. It is obvious that members of the Australian defence forces should not receive less pay than their Public Service counterparts. But, if that is the reason why the Air Force and the Navy hierarchy have decided to grant performance based pay to their senior officers, the same hierarchy should argue strenuously for better pay and conditions for its junior officers and other ranks.

It appears that only the Army consulted widely. As it is only the Army which has not implemented the scheme, I ask the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Senator Faulkner): what was the result of the Army's consultation which led it to reject the scheme? Am I right in guessing that the overwhelming majority of officers contacted rejected performance based pay? I also ask the Minister: when will junior officers and other ranks finally get the agency based productivity increases under tier three of the workplace bargaining agreement and when will their service allowance be increased?

Finally, I could not let the comments of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel today regarding improvements in Defence Force housing go without comment. With regard to my home State of South Australia and the RAAF base at Edinburgh, I ask Senator Faulkner whether he has ever visited any of the married quarters in the Munno Para, Elizabeth and Smithfield areas. Maybe after he has been to see for himself he would not stand up here and give such a glowing report of Defence Force housing. All he would need to do is talk to the wives of Defence Force members who are living in areas where they feel unsafe, where they feel threatened, where they literally sleep with knives or some other weapon under their pillows or by their beds when their husbands are away, where they are scared to go to the local shops, where there is graffiti in the street and where local troublemakers can easily identify Defence Force families and single them out for harassment. When we heard of the glowing reports of Defence Force housing by Senator Faulkner today, I wondered whether he has ever been to see—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been to see the new ones?

—Yes, I have been to see where some of them are already. It is all very well to talk about the new ones, but we are talking about the ones already in existence. I know of these three areas in particular where what I have said is quite true. Senator Faulkner referred to a study undertaken by the Defence Force Housing Authority which showed a high level of satisfaction with Defence housing. I simply ask the Minister whether that survey asked the families, particularly the wives whose husbands are regularly away, whether they felt comfortable or safe, whether they had ever been broken into, whether there had ever been prowlers at their houses or whether they had ever been subjected to harassment on the basis that they were from Defence families.

PARA.TAB: I believe it would be very instructive for the new Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to talk to the service personnel and their families directly. He would then know that performance based pay is causing extreme anger and that defence housing is the bane of a defence family's life and a major contributor to wives convincing their husbands that they ought to leave the defence forces. Yet again this Government has shown that it is out of touch with the community and, in this case, the defence community in particular. If any extra money should be spent in this particular area of defence personnel, it should be on increasing the service allowance and granting a service-wide pay increase, not performance based pay for a select few.

Many other matters have been raised, but for briefness I will comment on one or two other issues which I believe are very important at this stage. I am very glad that Senator Brownhill referred to the Alice Springs to Darwin railway, which is one of the most important issues confronting South Australians and people in the Northern Territory at present.

I was absolutely staggered to hear the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) say, a couple of weeks prior to the election on 13 March, that the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link would be of no benefit to South Australians. He said that people would bypass South Australia, and that the most important thing was the rail link between Adelaide and Melbourne. After he had made that statement—which prompted an initial response from people in all the areas directly affected—three days before the election the Prime Minister then said that he was prepared to commit $3 million to complete the survey of the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link.

I have never seen a more blatant election promise or election propaganda than that. It only emerged after members of the coalition had promised that they would complete that survey and would then give considerable consideration to the completion of that rail link. The Prime Minister offered a considerable amount of money, a financial inducement, to South Australia to get it out of the trouble it was in with regard to the dealings of the State Bank of South Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Six hundred million.

—He offered $600 million in order to help the South Australian economy, which has never been in a more parlous state than it is at present. Why would the Prime Minister not help South Australia to help itself by committing funds to help build the railway? This would then allow South Australian businesses to connect to the Asian market and enable them to help themselves, rather than receive a handout from the Federal Government. It is a decision that this Government has to make, but it would seem to me that it would be of far greater benefit to allow South Australians to help themselves rather than to give cash handouts to try to get them out of the trouble they are in because of their current State Labor Government.

PARA.TAB: I also would like to touch on the area of help to rural communities, which was mentioned previously by Senator Brownhill. In the last few months we have heard a lot from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) about the effect of his adjustment schemes and his grants to rural communities. In many cases what has been offered will really only touch the tip of the iceberg. I particularly refer to those people in rural communities who have shown enterprise and who have in the past made some outstanding achievements. I will refer to one particular case.

In order to fulfil the objective of trying to value-add to rural commodities and of trying to expand and diversify all the commodities that we have for sale in rural areas, some 18 months ago a young farmer on the Eyre Peninsula received the Young Achiever's Award in South Australia for an enterprise into quandong farming, which he did in conjunction with the rest of his rural enterprise. It was seen fit that he should be the young achiever in South Australia because of his decision to diversify and because of his enterprise in trying to value-add in an area that has undergone some horrendous problems due to drought, low commodity prices and then, last year, incessant rain, which ruined the crops of his normal harvest of wheat and peas.

I noticed in an article in the Adelaide Advertiser last week that this young man's farm was being sold up because he could not get any help through the rural adjustment scheme. Despite his having previously been the young achiever of the year and in spite of the hardships that he suffered at the last harvest because of most unseasonable rains—probably the worst we have ever had at harvest time in our history—this young man's farm was being sold, bar the 400 or 500 acres that were left for his quandong production for which he had received the young achiever award.

We need to encourage young people and young businessmen in rural communities to help them to survive through what are most difficult times—I concede that we have been through difficult times before, but this is one of the most difficult. If we cannot encourage young people to stay on the land—considering that the average age of our farmers is now 55 years—I wonder what future there is for our rural communities and for those great producers of export commodities which we hear about, and which are encouraged, day after day. Unless this Government sees fit to make sure that people with enterprise remain on the land, I see a very bleak future for our rural communities and those producers of the export earning income required to make this nation great again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the appropriation and supply Bills. In the lead-up to this Government's 1992-93 Budget, Australia finds itself in its most tragic economic position ever. We have a government presiding over one million unemployed, another one million under-employed and the most severe foreign debt problem in our history—$203 billion. The Government has been warned that the International Monetary Fund could well intervene in its economic decisions. We have a government that has blown out its own Budget debt to $16 billion. It is a government which has presided over the worst lowering of living standards on record. An unprecedented number of families just cannot make ends meet and have to rely on voluntary organisations for their survival.

PARA.TAB: I visited the City Mission the other day and I was told that a whole generation of youngsters believe that going to the supermarket is just not on; these days groceries are obtained from the City Mission. The Salvation Army backs up those statements. It is to me extraordinary that we have children who so regularly go with their mothers to get their groceries at these voluntary organisations that they believe only mugs go to the supermarket. We have a government that is so cynical towards the people of Australia that it was able to dupe them into believing that all the promises made prior to the election would be kept.

The Government, through the Governor-General's speech to the people of Australia at the opening of this Parliament, did not even mention the rural recession. It did not mention the farmers and it did not see fit to mention the dreadful situation in which the country people find themselves and which has been spoken about so well tonight by my colleagues.

I come back now to these promises that have not been kept: there are six. In two months we have had six promises broken—three a month. Not bad! For instance, one of the promises that was meant to start in July has been put off; it will arrive some time in the next three years. But I will mention just a few.

First of all, there was the promise that all people receiving any pension would no longer have to pay any tax by the year 1995. Many pensioners voted for the Government in the belief that that promise would be kept. It has already been broken, with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) saying that it certainly will not be abided by. Pensioners and health card holders were promised free emergency dental services starting from 1 July, but that promise has also been broken.

We were told by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) that 10,000 hospital bed days would be bought from the private hospitals every year to overcome waiting lists in public hospitals. Senator Richardson has assured us in this place that no, that promise will not be kept; he hopes to be able to spend the money to alleviate the queues but certainly he will not be able to spend the money on 10,000 private beds to alleviate that public hospital queue. Why was that, I wonder. It was because the Prime Minister spoke off the top of his head without referring to the private hospitals, and the private hospitals have told him that it is not on.

Mr Keating promised to match dollar for dollar all money raised by voluntary organisations in their Christmas appeals. Senator Crowley got into hot water in Question Time the other day when she said that that promise would be kept. Of course, it will not be kept. The Prime Minister changed the wording from `raised' to `spent', which makes a very big difference. In much the same way the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said that by the year 1990 no child would live in poverty. He, too, changed the words when he found there was no chance of being able to keep that promise.

We note that all these promises have affected the poor and pensioners, yet during the election this Government accused us of not caring and of not looking after the poor. The Council on the Ageing has already objected strongly to these promises being broken, but it is not being listened to. The next election is a long way off—in three years time. We have not forgotten that the Government's promised tax cuts do not apply to the poor. No-one earning under $20,700 will get any tax relief; it will apply only to those earning above that amount. Those above, yes; those below, no. Mr Keating's comment was, `We have already done enough for that mob'.

Do honourable senators remember the promise of a $30 a week child-care subsidy for mothers who stay home to look after their children? I am sure Senator Crowley and you, Madam Acting Deputy President, remember that promise. That promise will not be kept this financial year; it may not be kept next financial year—maybe it will be kept the year after that. We do not know. At no stage did the Prime Minister say that it would not be given until the last financial year. It was to be had from the beginning. We all know it is a great deceit because all the Prime Minister is doing is taking the dependent spouse rebate from the husband's wallet and giving it to the wife.

TALK.START.PARA: —Less $17.

—Less $17. What woman was told—and it was a plank of the Government's women's policy—that that promise really ripped $17 out of the family budget? No-one was told that. The final duplicity the Government has entered into is its acceptance and implementation of the coalition's industrial relations policy. The Prime Minister has now accepted workplace agreements and the eventual petering out of awards. At least the breaking of that promise will help the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: What is the result of all this? As a result we have a million unemployed. An engineer came to my office not long ago begging for any sort of job at all. He really felt that he had deserted his family. He had teenage children and it was the most expensive time in his life. He had applied for a job washing dishes in a hotel. He did not get it because he was told that he was overqualified; as he said, anyone can wash dishes. As an engineer he was told that he was overqualified and therefore was not given the job. The thought of one million unemployed should wipe the smile off the face of the Minister at the table, Senator Crowley.

We have more homeless youth than ever before. Children who are wandering the streets at night are not there because they are unable to accept discipline. They are out there because their families have deserted them, because of marriage breakdown and because—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all of them; some.

—Senator Burns should go out and have a look. We have already been and had a look. Our committee went around to all the shelters, had a look and talked to the people there. Those people were out there purely and simply because they had been thrown out. So Senator Burns should not interject until he goes out, has a look and knows what he is talking about. In the majority of cases young people are made homeless because of the breakdown of their families.

PARA.TAB: A further factor to be considered is the tremendous increase in the number of suicides. Research was recently undertaken by Mr Phil Rascal of the University of New South Wales who stated:

SPEECH.PARA: 80 to 90 per cent of variations in homicides and suicides in the last decade—
that is, since this Government has been in power—
are directly linked to changes in the levels of inequality. And it should be remembered that the level of suicides in Australia, now, exceeds that of deaths in motor vehicle accidents.

The increase in the number of suicides in Australia, taking the last figures, was 9.2 per cent. In my State of Tasmania the figure went up 51 per cent in one year—mainly in the country areas in the north west. That is where the rural recession is hitting hardest, yet this Government cannot even mention it. In the Governor-General's speech at the opening of Parliament, a speech that lasted an hour and a half, the rural recession was not even mentioned. In Tasmania, I repeat that the suicide rate went up 51 per cent and for every suicide about 100 are attempted.

PARA.TAB: What is the Government doing to remedy this situation? We know what the Prime Minister is doing. All he is doing is talking about a republic. The Prime Minister is the most racist person I have ever struck. All he can talk about is the British—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not think it is appropriate for the honourable senator to suggest that the Prime Minister is a racist. I ask you to request her to withdraw that remark.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Senator Walters, I am wondering whether you need to use such excessive language. I will not rule it unparliamentary, but I think it is unfitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe it is excessive. We have heard, in this Parliament and in the community, the way in which the Prime Minister has spoken about the British. We have heard him rewrite history. When handed an Australian flag by Mr Garland he handed it back saying, `Give it to one of your pommie friends'.

—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I would have thought it was quite clearly unparliamentary and inappropriate for anyone in this place to refer to any member, let alone the Prime Minister, as racist. Will Senator Walters withdraw that remark? According to the Standing Orders it is unparliamentary and she should withdraw it.

—On the point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President, the definition of `racist' need not have connotations of colour or whatever. It applies if somebody is talking about one race being different from another race.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—I certainly believe, as I ruled before, that the term is inappropriate. I felt it was a rather unfortunate use of language. I do not quite know how Senator Walters was going to substantiate the accusation. Senator Walters should avoid using that sort of inflammatory language because it adds nothing to the debate. TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. As I said, all the Prime Minister is doing is talking about a republic. He should be taking other action to right the economic situation in which Australia finds itself.

PARA.TAB: So what should the Government be doing? I believe that it should be implementing that section of Fightback that takes the taxes off business. We all remember the time during the election campaign when the Prime Minister walked into the baker's shop and the baker said to him, `You take the $40,000 payroll tax off my back and I will employ two people tomorrow'.

TALK.START.PARA: —So he finished up with cream on his face.

—The Prime Minister certainly did. If the Prime Minister or the Government took payroll tax, wholesale sales tax, the superannuation levy and the petrol levy off the back of business, business could at least get going again and employ people.

PARA.TAB: What is the situation now? What has the Government decided to do about unemployment? We read in today's Australian Financial Review that a new Caucus committee will be established to produce a report on the long-term unemployed. That will be a big help—another committee set up to have a look at the long-term unemployed! Mr Beazley is telling us we will have half a million long-term unemployed for many years to come. What a defeatist attitude!

We do not have to accept this sort of long-term unemployment. We have only to create the situation where business can expand and thus employ more people. But because it will not we will have headlines such as: `Locals hurt as NZ manufactures hit record'. We have Heinz, Gillette, Glaxo, Kraft, Unilever, the Australian division of Lever & Kitchen, Rexona, and Consolidated Apparel Industries of Adelaide all moving to New Zealand where, they say, production costs are up to 50 per cent less. So why would they not move to New Zealand? No wonder there is a dreadful feeling of hopelessness as the unemployed see all those companies moving offshore to New Zealand. There is no chance of them getting a job while so many of our industries move to New Zealand.

We are now left with a government that will promise or do anything in an election campaign to get the votes. It is now two months after the election and six election promises have already been broken. The Government has duped the people this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It fooled the Greens last time and duped the women this time.

—Yes, it has. It has duped the women, the unemployed and Australia. I believe the Government will find at the next election a reaction like the one in 1975. Mr Keating will be thrown out in exactly the same way as Gough Whitlam was, with an overwhelming majority going to the Opposition.
