TALK.START.PARA: —I will raise issues similar to this in a few moments upon reaching the reservations on program 8 for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs section. But, given that the report of Estimates Committee A lists a very large number of unanswered questions for this entire committee. I would like some information from the Minister as to why there have been no substantive replies to what probably must be many more than 100 or so unanswered questions for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. As I said, I am specifically interested in the 34 questions listed against my name with regard to ATSIC. But this matter concerns much more than just the issue of ATSIC and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs section generally.

PARA.TAB: I notice that many questions are listed in the names of Senators Kemp, Bishop, Crane, Archer, O'Chee, Harradine, Short, Boswell, Chapman and Brownhill to which the committee deserves an answer. It is highly unsatisfactory to have such a large number of unanswered questions. I hope that my comments have perhaps alerted some of my colleagues to the fact that the issues that they raised two weeks ago before the Senate estimates committee have not yet received adequate or satisfactory replies. As I mentioned earlier, I will certainly address my comments under specific reservations, but I think there is a very general question that needs to be answered as to why this department has not accounted to this committee for what must be between 100 and 200 unanswered questions of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, but I heard only half of Senator Tambling's comments on this. I am advised that the reason why there are insufficient substantive replies to the questions that were asked on notice is that the Minister only got back from overseas this morning and simply has not had time to look at the drafts and to clear them. He will obviously do so as soon as humanly possible. I will take further advice on the questions Senator Tambling has raised.

—I appreciate that the answer given by the Minister relates only to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs part of the portfolio. Mr Chairman, my concern under the issue you have raised of unanswered questions is that the whole Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is guilty of not providing answers for between at least 100 and 200 unanswered questions. I appreciate that there are 30-odd questions that specifically relate to the issues I wish to pursue in the Aboriginal area, for which the Minister has just offered the feeble excuse that the Minister was out of the country. That is only one Minister and there has been an Acting Minister in the interim who ought properly have dealt with it, given the nature of the issues that are gong to be raised, and that I am certainly going to raise, tonight. I am very concerned that these hundreds of outstanding questions across the entire range of the report of Estimates Committee A, which is the issue that we are addressing here, have not been answered.

—I am advised that the questions to the department itself have, in fact, been answered; the only questions that are outstanding are those as to ATSIC. That is my advice; I am not in a position to second-guess that. With regard to the tabular material at the back of the report and questions from Senators Campbell, Harradine and so on for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the answers are recorded there as having been sent to senators variously on 19 May.

—Mr Chairman, I draw your attention to the fact that we are dealing with Estimates Committee A under the non-portfolio specific issues. You have asked us to address three points, the third one of which was unanswered questions. The tabular forms at the back of this report list, after the list that is attributable to my name, between 100 and 200 unanswered questions of other senators. I am keen to know for the information of committee A when we will receive all of those answers. There are obviously between 100 and 200 still to be addressed.

—So far as PM&C is concerned, that is exhausted on the first tabular page. So far as ATSIC is concerned, I have just given Senator Tambling the response I can there. Then we get on to Foreign Affairs and Trade, which is referred to on subsequent pages. My clear understanding is that all those questions from my department have, in fact, now been put in, even though they were not in time to appear in the text of the report. Perhaps the Chairman of the Committee can help us in that respect.

—Today I tabled answers to questions on Estimates Committee A. Last week I did also. They have certainly been distributed. I do not know whether that assists in any way. It certainly confirms what Senator Evans is saying—that they were tabled early today.

—Mr Chairman, the point I make is that, given the early start to this matter, some of my colleagues might not well have been alerted—as I said—to all of these outstanding questions for Estimates Committee A. I ask that you reserve the position on unanswered questions and that, if any other senator wishes to pursue that matter, he or she be given that right. He or she might not have had the opportunity to appreciate that they have had the answers to questions that Senator Childs has tabled today. I certainly have not received any of the answers to the 34 unanswered questions that are attributed to my name. I will take the opportunity under the reservations to pursue those issues. But I would hope that you will hold over consideration. If necessary, at the end of consideration of Estimates Committee A, I will move for the postponement of further committee consideration until such time as adequate consideration has been given to the committee.

—I am now able to advise, on advice, that all the unanswered questions here referred to in this tabular formation from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have been replied to and submitted either at the end of last week or today, as the case may be. Similarly for Primary Industries and Energy, the remaining five pages of this tabular formation, those questions, were all put in last Friday, I am advised, and have been sent to the committee.

PARA.TAB: Given the short time period between the Estimates Committee A hearings and this Committee of the Whole, and given the complexity and range of the matters involved, that seems to me to be a not unreasonable performance. I regret that Senator Tambling has not had the answers he wants in relation to ATSIC, but I have explained the particular circumstance relating to that. I suggest that there is no reason whatsoever to delay the consideration of the rest of the committee report for the reasons that he has been concerned about.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that we are looking at unanswered questions in the whole of the report. As Chairman, I would be willing to leave this until we get to the end of the report, but I think that when we get to the end of the report we had better go back and see how we go from there.

—One further piece of advice I have just been given: of the ATSIC questions, of which there are a total of about 40, about 24, I am told, are now with the Minister. The remaining questions are, in fact, about the Northern Land Council, which it is not directly within ATSIC's capacity to respond to. The best ATSIC can do is what it has done, and that is seek answers from the Northern Land Council, which may still take some time. So far as the other questions are concerned, we will simply get the answers to Senator Tambling as soon as possible—maybe, with a bit of luck, later tonight; I am not sure.

—If it is the wish of the Committee we will move on to specific matters within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, coming back to those unanswered questions at the end of our deliberations on Estimates Committee A. Senator Tambling, I understand you wish to speak on program 8, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I refer to the running sheet that you have distributed. I note that a number of items listed are similar to, but in a different order from, the reservation that I filed as part of the report of Estimates Committee A. I draw the attention of the chamber and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Evans) to the comments in the report of the estimates committee, specifically on this program. Clause 17 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling sought extensive and detailed information from ATSIC concerning a number of issues, particularly the activities of the Northern Land Council. He drew the Committee's attention to a significant qualification by the Auditor-General of the Council's Annual Report.
Clause 18 states:

Senator Tambling asked whether any additional section 64(7) funding had been approved by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs following receipt of the qualified audit report. This matter was taken on notice by ATSIC officers. No reply has been received to date.
Clause 19 states:

The Chief Executive Officer, Dr P. Shergold, informed the Committee that the Minister took the audit qualifications very seriously and had sought assurances from the Council that it has implemented procedures to avoid overspending in the future. The Minister has also approached the Auditor-General seeking advice on whether any matters in the audit report require further investigation.
Clause 20 states:
The Committee notes that this matter may require further investigation following receipt of additional information.

Mr Chairman, I draw clause 20 specifically to your attention and that of the Minister. This report has been available to the officers and, therefore, they ought to have known that this committee needed the information in order to conduct the process that is going on here this evening. The answers that have obviously been made available to the Minister or the Acting Minister, whoever he or she may have been, in the last fortnight are very important. I do not accept Senator Evans's statement that that is an excuse. Government always operates on the basis that, if the Minister is out of the country, there is an Acting Minister, who, in this case, could have drawn this matter to finality and presented it earlier for the consideration of the estimates committee and of the committee tonight.

PARA.TAB: A number of issues were directly related to the activities and responsibility of ATSIC. I separate them from those of the Northern Land Council, and I do that very specifically. In estimates committee last September, I asked similar questions, though not as extensive, with regard to the activities of the Northern Land Council. The answers on that matter which were tabled were received in final form by the Senate estimates committee only in recent weeks. Various draft pieces were dribbled in. The Minister obviously showed that he had no capacity to direct or to offer assistance in any way whatsoever with regard to the activities of the Northern Land Council.

I refer to section 64(7) funding—and the Minister's credibility is very much at stake here—which is approved by the Minister and which is very necessary for ATSIC to receive additional funding. In the estimates committee two weeks ago, I pursued this matter very deliberately and very intentionally. The Minister signed that approval, whatever it was and for whatever amounts, and, therefore, the available information ought to have been provided within a day or so. I am not worried that the Minister can now wave it under my nose a fortnight later and expect me to respond to it here in the chamber because he has managed to drag it out of the Minister's office or somewhere else. The fact is that it was not provided to the Senate committee or the chamber in an appropriate form.

I would have thought the seriousness of the issues that I raised two weeks ago, with regard to the Minister providing additional amounts of money and the qualifications that the Auditor-General and the auditors of the Northern Land Council have raised with the Northern Land Council, would have sent bells ringing throughout government as to the serious nature of funding for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory—that it is obviously being perverted or diverted in many ways.

I would also have expected some sort of formal discussion here this evening about the availability of information from the Northern Land Council. I appreciate the delicate relationship between ATSIC as the intermediary body and the Northern Land Council. I appreciate that in those sensitive relationships ATSIC itself is not responsible for the activities of the Northern Land Council. But the Minister certainly is, and the Minister's agent, ATSIC in this area, ought to have been able within a fortnight to have conveyed the seriousness of this problem to the Northern Land Council and demanded of it all the information to the 30 or 40 questions that were asked on 10 May.

The questions were all set out very clearly. They were all available in Hansard the next day, 11 May. As we have seen with many other departments, the information ought to have been provided and should well have been provided here. There are many issues in that area that related to Aboriginal employment, to the royalty trust accounts, the funds that flowed to many Aboriginal people throughout the Northern Territory and the discretionary payments for administration of the Minister from the ABTA.

The Minister might remember that at the estimates committee there was considerable discussion about a so-called internal audit report into the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account. Mr Miller at first denied that any such report existed and, in questioning at the estimates, it was subsequently ascertained that the report had been tabled and presented to ATSIC. Why have we not got an answer here as to whether that report, in all of its seriousness, was to be made available to the committee for consideration before this stage?

There was also the matter of the personal debts of the Chairman of the Northern Land Council, Mr Galarrwuy Yunupingu. It had been alleged to me that he owed some $25,000 as a personal debt to the Northern Land Council. What sort of operation do we think this Government is running in allowing the Northern Land Council to operate as the private banker of its statutorily appointed chairman? I ask the question very deliberately whether any other executive members or council members of the Northern Land Council had their fingers in the till for topping up funds in any way. That personal debt very much raises the whole issue of conflict of interest of the Chairman of the Northern Land Council, his capacity to operate and whether he had received any counselling from ATSIC, the Minister or any other officer of Government on that particular matter.

There was also the matter that I had raised with the Minister himself in January with regard to fringe benefits rorts by senior staff and management of land councils. These are important issues. It is a very serious matter if, as has been alleged in correspondence to me, the land councils were avoiding considerable responsibility on a comparable basis. The Minister acknowledged that there were some 30 or 40 outstanding questions in this area. What annoys me is that those serious matters, raised now a fortnight ago, are not back here for proper consideration, the only feeble excuse being that the Minister was out of the country. I am not surprised that Mr Tickner wants to look at the answers. He personally signed any forms that made additional funding under section 64(7). As there are serious implications arising from the qualified audit reports of his subsidiary body and as he has subsequently approved additional funding, perhaps there is some personal sensitivity.

That ought not to be seen in any way as a camouflage for the Minister's responsibility or for that of ATSIC acting as agent, and particularly for the Northern Land Council which has a very direct responsibility to thousands of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory on behalf of whom it has to exercise a care of trust. I am bitterly disappointed. I will look to the Minister for some answers on this issue. If I do not receive adequate answers this evening, there will be no alternative but to move that consideration of the estimates of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet be postponed until such time as the answers are forthcoming.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a position to make available now to Senator Tambling—whether he desperately wants it right now or not—at least the answer to the factual question that was raised about additional section 64(7) grants. There have been just over $4 million of such grants to the Northern Land Council and $2.3 million to the Central Land Council. I now table that detailed reply in the event that Senator Tambling might be interested in it.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the matter of the qualified audit raised in paragraph 19 of the report of Estimates Committee A, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has referred this matter to the Auditor-General. A response is not yet available. I am afraid that is the best we can do by way of giving further and better particulars on that specific matter.

As to the other questions that are in draft form awaiting the Minister's attention, all I can say is that a message has been sent to the Minister. It is to be hoped that it will be possible for him to give some attention to this matter tonight, otherwise I am afraid the matter will have to wait until tomorrow.

I mention again that there is nothing whatsoever in the additional appropriations for ATSIC which bear upon the NLC. In those circumstances the jurisdictional basis for these current fulminations seems a bit tenuous, to say the least. I understand Senator Tambling's concern to get these answers. I do not think it is entirely reasonable for him to be critical of the Minister's need to look at these matters when he has been out of the country for the last eight or nine days, which is almost the whole period since the estimates committee hearings were held. The Minister has only got back today. We will get the answers to Senator Tambling as soon as we possibly can. As I say, I have urged that that be expedited.

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to ascertain whether the answers that are hopefully before the Minister in draft form for his consideration are in respect of all the listed questions in the report, or are only those that relate specifically to the purview and the activities of ATSIC.

—I have already answered that, Mr Chairman. I have said that about 24 answers are with the Minister. The remaining ones concern the NLC and as a result are not yet able to be addressed by the Minister. They will be addressed in due course, presumably when replies are received from the NLC. Manifestly, that process is a little more lengthy than matters that are within the immediate capacity and responsibility of ATSIC to answer for itself.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling will possibly get his ATSIC answers later tonight—certainly tomorrow—as soon as Mr Tickner can look at them, but I am afraid he will have to wait a bit longer for the NLC answers. As Senator Tambling is a reasonable person, I am sure he will understand the particular constraints that we have in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) says that we will have to wait for the production of answers from ATSIC and the Northern Land Council, it might well mean that further consideration of the estimates of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet will equally have to wait. That is only reasonable, given that both bodies have had a fortnight in which to respond to the requests made, and also given the fact that last week the committee in paragraph 20 of its report drew specific attention to this, noting that further investigation would be necessary following receipt of the additional information.

PARA.TAB: I would have hoped that the matter could have been resolved this evening; unfortunately it seems that that will not happen. Therefore, it will be necessary to wait a couple of days until we can get the answers from both ATSIC and the Northern Land Council in order to approve the estimates of the committee.

The answer that has just been passed to me by the Minister specifically relates to section 64(7). I note, very importantly, that in the grants to the Northern Land Council in this financial year there have been these additional payments of some $4 million. I am very concerned about that with regard to any changes in the budget approvals of the Northern Land Council. I think its annual operating budget is currently in the order of $8 million. If it has had to be topped up by an additional 50 per cent in this financial year there is a very serious matter going on, and a very serious matter of approvals that need the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), who has obviously signed each and every one of those approvals. Also, in the normal course of events, any additional expenditure would naturally have shown in the appropriate accounts presented to the Parliament for consideration.

The fact is that these funds are channelled through the Aboriginals benefit trust account. That means that when they are made available to the land councils for additional administrative expenses, those funds are not then available for general community grants to Aboriginal people in my constituency in the Northern Territory. So it is all right for the Minister to say that there are no additional funds being allocated—there are. The process is just that they are channelled through a trust account and they are specifically being drawn against funds that would otherwise be available for the provision of very worthwhile and necessary benefits for Aboriginal people. Here, by ministerial fiat and approval, they are being syphoned off and used for purely administrative functions of a land council that is under review by the Auditor-General, and that has had a qualified audit report in the last financial year that would certainly have been before the Minister for his consideration before the dates of some of these grant approvals.

I say to the Minister that this is a very serious matter. I would hope that he would acknowledge that the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory are the people who are missing out on these benefits. They are the people making representations to me as their senator about the concerns of the Northern Land Council—the constituents. There is considerable controversy not only with regard to the administration of this trust account—which is the Commonwealth Government's Aboriginals benefit trust account—but also the unanswered question of the royalty trust accounts that are separately maintained by the Northern Land Council, which I believe are being syphoned off and used for additional and further administrative costs. Those issues need to be very carefully addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling ought to be well aware that the reason for drawing upon the reserves of the trust account in this way is simply that mineral royalties revenue is down as a result of prices being down and production being down. I am advised that, under those circumstances, there is a necessity to draw on, in effect, the reserve account. It is perfectly true that it is undesirable, and that we would infinitely prefer to be able to rely on current revenue from the mining royalties. But when they are down and the expenditure has to be met, this is the way that is provided for; this is the way it has been met. There is nothing irregular or unusual about this. It is just a function of those economic circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Again, if Senator Tambling could curb some of the synthetic indignation that he is demonstrating on this, as on other occasions, we might be able to move a little faster. He knows better than I do, because I am only acting on advice at the moment, what the reality of the situation is, and that is it.

As to all this business about holding up the estimates and so on, it is fair enough for Senator Tambling to expect answers on the ATSIC questions, and I have undertaken to do everything I possibly can to get those here either tonight or first thing tomorrow. All I can say about the NLC material is that we will do our best to get it in the time available, but Senator Tambling has to acknowledge the obvious difficulties that are involved when one is dependent on information from bodies not immediately within one's capacity to control. That is the difficulty we have at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take offence at the words of the Minister for Foreign Affairs in describing my comments as synthetic indignation. Twenty-five to 30 per cent of my constituents are Aboriginal people. I am sure that if this sort of activity were taking place in the portfolio interests closer to the Minister's heart, such as South Africa or Cambodia or Eritrea or Ethiopia and the matter involved these sorts of funds, he would not in any way be lambasting me. I would hope that under his portfolio responsibilities such problems would not become apparent.

PARA.TAB: On five occasions this financial year funds totalling $4 million—50 per cent of the land council's budget—have had to be appropriated in addition to the approved budget earlier presented to the Minister. That is not synthetic indignation, Minister; it is a matter of disgrace and shame. Every one of those five appropriations has required the approval of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). On each occasion he would have been aware of the very serious matters that were before the Northern Land Council, either from management reports, internal audit reports, the audit report of the Northern Land Council itself or, now, the fact that he has had to accept responsibility for the matter being deferred for consideration by the Auditor-General. The amounts are not insignificant. On each occasion they have been between half a million dollars and $1.2 million. The people who are missing out on the realisation of this matter are individual constituents not able to apply to the Aboriginals benefit trust account for other grants.

The other issue that I raised in the estimates committee hearing and for which I am still awaiting answers relates to the consultancies within the Northern Land Council. This is a very serious matter because I made the allegation that there was a considerable degree of nepotism involved. People who have received money under those grants are very clearly identified with the families of the senior echelon of the Northern Land Council. In fact, many of them are very closely aligned with the Australian Labor Party as well.

This is a serious matter. It is a matter of denying proper benefits. It is a matter on which I have had considerable representation from Aboriginal constituents within the electorate. I am surprised and amazed that the Minister is still hedging on this issue and cannot accept the seriousness of the matter and the need for all questions to be fully answered before these appropriations are approved. I intend to move that the consideration of the estimates of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet be postponed until the production of the answers for program 8.

TALK.START.PARA: —That motion will not be accepted. Obviously we will make every possible effort to get the answers in the circumstances I have described. I think Senator Tambling is being quite unreasonable.
—Put it off till tomorrow; it will waste less time.

—I am happy to postpone further consideration of PM&C until tomorrow. I would appreciate it if Senator Tambling would delete that latter condition. I am just not able to say whether it will be physically possible to give Senator Tambling the answers to all those questions tomorrow. It certainly will be possible to give him the ATSIC answers by tomorrow.
—We can put it off until tomorrow without any commitment.
—Can we, by consent, put further consideration of PM&C off until tomorrow?
—I foreshadow that I may still move that motion.
—I understand that perfectly.

—Under those circumstances, with the concurrence of the committee, we will move to consideration of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. There being no questions on the non-portfolio specific issues—performance pay, provision of additional information and unanswered questions—we will move on to matters raised in the report, beginning with program 1, subprogram 1, relations with Asia. Senator Bishop raised a matter by way of reservation, as did Senator Crane.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the question of what the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has done to ease the current crisis in the wool market. I preface my remarks by saying that I raised that matter during the Estimates Committee A hearing not only under this particular program and program 8 but also during the consideration of the estimates of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. My continuing concern has been that there does not appear to be any coordination between the activities of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Austrade, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge at the outset that, after I raised my concerns at the estimates hearings, the Minister for Trade (Senator Cook)—who is presently overseas—arranged for discussions to take place tomorrow morning between me and Austrade, and on Thursday with officers from his department. Having said that, it is worth noting that the answers I have so far received clearly confirm my concerns, and that this confirmation comes at a time when, as I have already mentioned, the wool industry is in serious crisis. The nature of that crisis has not changed during the last 2 1/2 years. Perhaps it would be more appropriate to pursue the matter I have raised when we look into the activities of Austrade and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.
In an answer given during the Additional Estimates hearing, Mr Delofski said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not aware that we are closely involved in the issue that you have identified.

The point I wish to make to the Minister—and I emphasise this—is that this crisis has been with us for almost three years. As I said earlier today, the types of structures that will identify the opportunities that exist for alternative uses of the product or other areas of research have not been put in place. My plea in raising the matter during the debate on the appropriation Bills and again now is for the Government to address in a constructive manner the implementation of a system or mechanism—I have called it a research coordination unit—which would coordinate the different pieces of information held by the various arms of the department and other government bodies so that the existing problems can be objectively and sensibly addressed.

PARA.TAB: We are dealing with a broad range of things when talking about this particular problem. One answer that was given to us says that, to date, Austrade has no formal relationship or communication with the Wool Realisation Commission. We can tie that back to the answer that was given to us by Mr Delofski in estimates, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not aware that we are closely involved in the issue that you have identified . . .
Yet in other answers that we have been given it is acknowledged that information is tied up in these various arms of government or deep in the bowels of the various departments.

PARA.TAB: I believe that we have a crisis situation before us. It is easy to stand here and be critical of the Government; it deserves to be criticised for the time that this has been going on. I make a plea to the Minister at the table, Senator Evans, as well as to Minister Cook, with whom I will continue this line of questioning when he returns, and to Minister Crean to address this issue in a proper and fundamental way and put some coordinating process in place so that the information, the research capability and the extension that we have into various parts of the world can be put together to identify solutions to the problem we have now.

It is well known—it has been highlighted in the press—that a number of people have different ideas about solving these problems. They have been described in terms ranging from `having prospects' to `snake oil theories'. I will continue my campaign on this problem until it is absolutely solved. Until such time as the Government gets serious about this matter and we start reducing that stockpile in a rational and sensible way, rather than have it remain as an albatross, not only to wool producers but to all those people involved in the industry—and the Australian economy, which is currently losing between $1 billion and $2 billion of export income a year—it deserves to be pursued relentlessly. I say to the Minister at the table that the time for talking is over and the time for action has arrived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the force of the points that Senator Crane has made. I think some of his concerns were answered to some extent by Senator Cook during the second stage of the estimates committee hearings on 12 May. That has been supplemented by various pieces of written information.

PARA.TAB: So far as Austrade is concerned, there has been a written answer relating to Senator Crane's question on page 123 of Hansard about Australian penetration of the wool market and again on the coordination of Austrade with the Wool Realisation Commission. In relation to the question he asked on page A74 of Hansard, he has had a detailed written response in terms of the nature and extent of the expertise that we put into our wool marketing effort in Asia.

I am able to advise Senator Crane further that my department has set up an internal task force to coordinate the department's efforts to promote Australian wool sales overseas, recognising that that expertise is somewhat scattered around the various geographical parts of the department and there may well be a need to gather together the threads, as it were, in this way. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to follow up the question of performance based pay raised by Senator Kemp. The question that I asked is recorded on page 10 of Additional Information Received Volume 1. I expressed then the feeling of most Australians that the concept of secret pay unidentified to individuals in the Public Service is totally and utterly unacceptable. It is just as unacceptable as a secret pool of money being dispensed to various Ministers who were seen to be better or worse than other Ministers. PARA.TAB: In accordance with that, I want to read a departmental minute and the real motive behind this secret pool of money and this secret allocation of money. It is a Foreign Affairs and Trade minute paper, file date 30 March 1990, signed by the then departmental head and sent to Mr Costello, departmental secretary—who I understand is to be the new departmental head—and Mr Forrester, well known to us for many other affairs including the Marshall Islands. I think Mr Miles Kupa came into that category as well. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Remuneration Tribunal.

Graham Glenn said that the Industrial Relations Commission would be considering performance pay for the SES on 20 April. He told me that he had heard that there was considerable concern in our SES about the introduction of performance pay. He hoped that we would not rock the boat before 20 April. If we were to reject performance pay the probability was that the department would simply not be given the funds by Finance while other departments would be given the funding.

2. In response to one of the particular problems I mentioned, Glenn said that he thought it was likely the Industrial Relations Commission would agree to a `middle of the way' approach for statutory bodies (i.e. 50%) and he thought that this could give us a basis to apply that formula, if we wished to do so, in respect of HOMs overseas.
The next paragraph is the really telling paragraph. It states:

3. Glenn conceded that performance pay was originally seen as a means of gaining a salary increase but this could not be said publicly or to the Commission. He agreed the system was flawed and had special difficulties for Foreign Affairs and Trade but said that he hoped that, on balance, we would accept it and make the best of it.

That is an indictment by the hand of Mr Richard Woolcott of a system which has got to be the most disgraceful blot upon the record of public accountability this nation has ever seen. Secret pools of money given secretly to individual officers in accordance with a secret formula—is that public accountability?

PARA.TAB: How would it be if we suddenly had a secret pool of money for Ministers? How much for Senator Evans? How much for Senator Collins? How would we allocate it? Would Senator Collins attract a good performance based pay? If he were a mate he might because there is the suggestion that much of the performance based pay in this department is done on a mate basis. How do we know it is not? We do not know the criteria. We do not know who is first best friend with whom or how it is to be allocated because it is all a secret.

The commissioners in the WA Inc. royal commission said that there was a cosying up—a relationship between the executive and the bureaucracy—which allowed corruption to take place. The reason that corruption took place was that the Parliament did not ask the hard questions. This Parliament is asking the hard questions. I seek leave to table this minute paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate it into Hansard.
—I have read it into Hansard, I also want the document tabled.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The hard question is: how is this Parliament charged with the responsibility of ensuring that there is correct expenditure of taxpayers' money? Bear in mind that the money given to the chosen few, the first best friends who get the allocation of money, is not to be disclosed and taxpayers are not to know where their money has gone.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp has asked the question about Mr Miles Kupa, well known for his involvement in the Marshall Islands affair. How are we to know on what basis he got a so-called special payment? How are we to know which officers have been rewarded for doing precisely what? That is the essence of the sort of thing that breeds corruption. If the officers of the SES in this department want their names to be clean and held high, then they ought to be the people clamouring at the gates to say, `Disclose what we got and why we got it'. Let us see what the criterion is and who made the decision. Who made the decision to say, `You can have some and you can't'? Who made the decision to say, `Your work is better than somebody else's'? Where is the objective criterion by which the taxpayer can say, `My money was wisely spent or not wisely spent'?

Out there in ordinary, struggling Australia, where people are having to tighten their belts, where is the belt tightening going on for this brigade of people who, in the words of the head of the department, say that it has been reported that this scheme is only for `gaining a salary increase'; one under the lap if you like? How do we expect to earn the respect of ordinary Australians while we have payments being made secretly to selected officers? And there is nothing on the record to say why it is so.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs has come under a cloud again and again with the Burkegate affair, the Marshall Islands affair, and, lastly, the Gillespie affair—different criteria, but on every occasion we see there is room to criticise the Minister. With regard to Burke, again and again honourable senators from this side rose and said, `Why, Senator Evans, will you not investigate the deplorable appointment of this man Burke'? Is it not amazing that, come his prosecution, suddenly a critical file goes missing?

Then we came to the Marshall Islands affair. The Minister held himself at arm's length—there was lots of paddling going on underneath. Finally the Minister had to stand down. Who were the people who were rewarded? The public want to know, the public are entitled to know because the Government has no money at all. Government can only dispense money which it first takes from the people. Therefore, in our system of governance, it is the members of the Parliament who are responsible for reporting to the people how their money is spent. If we do not ask the hard questions, then the questions will not be answered. I would put it you, Mr Chairman, that it is not only a question for members on the opposition side to ask, but it is also the responsibility of backbenchers of the Labor Party because they are no more members of the Government than I am. They are elected with the same responsibility that I am elected. That responsibility is to ensure that taxpayers' money is properly spent.

Here on this issue we have it admitted that piles of money are being allocated secretly to chosen officers. There is no accountability, no criterion to be answered for, and nobody to answer whether it is a secret commission or anything else.

It is simply not proper and it must be disclosed. I would put it to the members of the SES who have been on the handout end that it is in their best interests to have the whole system disclosed and to have it put on the public record so as to put themselves above the suspicion of the public—suspicion which the public is entitled to have at the present time. It is the most horrendous principle that has been introduced, and one that very simply must not be allowed to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope Senator Bishop feels better after all of that. Not a great deal of it was specifically directed to the matter immediately in issue, which is the performance pay operation. Let me just make a couple of things clear. For a start, there is no performance pay system in place for SES officers at all, including people like Mr Kupa who have long been in that particular band. The performance pay system that is in place at the moment is for senior officers below the SES level—that is, SOGBs and SOGCs in public service parlance—and, as such, quite a deal of Senator Bishop's fulmination about particular individuals is, not unusually, quite astray.
—The secrecy provisions remain constant.

—As to the alleged secrecy provisions, I am advised that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is acting in this respect wholly in accordance with general public service guidelines. Those guidelines, widely promulgated and agreed in the middle of last year I think, make it clear that appraisal and review records for individuals are appropriately the subject of privacy protection and that third parties would not have access under FOI to such records generated in the course of a performance appraisal process.

PARA.TAB: My department has taken the view that that privacy protection extends to the final conclusion and the recommendation that is made to pay, if is actually paid. My understanding, although I am in the course of checking that, is that that is exactly the system that is applied Public Service-wide. If there is any variation from department to department in the policy that is adopted in relation to disclosure of the actual decisions made, I would be glad to hear of it from Senator Bishop, who knows everything about everything, as we are well aware from the past. If she does know everything about the way in which the system operates elsewhere, maybe she will share some of that knowledge with us. She is usually not slow to do so.

It needs to be appreciated that the orders of magnitude for these performance pay top-ups are not spectacularly large. For example, for SOGCs a rating of three gives a person an additional $1,284 and a rating of five gives a person $2,000, and the difference is between $3,300 and $5,200 respectively for SOGBs. These are not huge percentages of the basic salary; they are there by way of inducement for effective performance. Although Senator Bishop fulminates on this subject with great passion and great indignation, I cannot imagine that she would be unaware of the extent to which there are incentive agreements of this kind in place almost universally in more senior levels of the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the public sector, sir.
—Indeed. But this is part of the whole process of making people basically more conscious of the need for effective performance. That is as much as I can say by way of answer at this stage.
—It is inadequate.

—I would jump handstands the full length of this chamber if Senator Bishop were ever prepared to acknowledge that an answer I gave her on any subject was even barely adequate, so Senator Bishop will forgive me if I am not unduly flustered by her characterisation of my response on this occasion. There are privacy guidelines that have been regarded as applicable. There is nothing private about the basic system that operates. Being a person of sensitivity and taste with respect for individual rights, as Senator Bishop often claims to be, I am sure she appreciates the force of that argument in this case in the way it applies.

—Following Senator Evans's response to Senator Bishop's question, some matters need to be clarified urgently. As far as I am aware, although they have not received performance based pay to the present time, members of the SES will become eligible for performance based pay after 1 July.

PARA.TAB: I would not want people to be misled by some of the information Senator Evans gave regarding cash bonuses for senior officers grade A, B and C. My understanding is that, for the upper bands of the SES, some of the performance based pay will amount to a cash bonus. The cash bonus for the so-called group 5, the outstanding group, will be in the order of $15,000 per person—certainly between $8,000 and $15,000. That applies to other departments certainly, and I would be interested to see whether it applies to the Minister's department.

I would like Senator Evans to confirm, firstly, when the upper bands of the SES—the Mr Costellos of this world—become entitled to performance based pay and, secondly, what is the maximum amount they can receive under performance based pay. I would like the Minister to address those two questions.

Senator Bishop's remarks raised a very important issue. There have been, before the estimates committee and before this chamber, examples of Ministers dumping on public servants. I do not find that a particularly edifying spectacle. I think the Minister has at times hidden behind people in the Public Service for errors which, under more traditional processes, I suspect he would have been held responsible for.

We have recently had before this chamber problems in relation to the Department of Transport and Communications. Senior public servants have been held by so-called independent reports to have not performed particularly well. It is of concern just how performance based pay relates to these particular people. Senator Bishop has raised a real dilemma.

I can see that in the coming round of estimates committees, after the Budget session, people will look at some of the major errors which have occurred in departments and see whether performance based pay has been awarded to particular individuals which Ministers have been prepared to name and hide behind. I think the public would be shocked if a public servant who had perhaps been named by a Minister or an independent report as being involved in a department which had clearly made a major bungle received a significant amount of performance based pay.

The Minister can make somewhat curt and unpleasant comments to Senator Bishop—he is entitled to do that; he is a Minister and he has a name for doing those sorts of things—but I think there are fundamental issues of public policy involved here. I think it is a dilemma. The Senate chamber would like to see whether Senator Evans can make a contribution so that we can see a way out of this. We can then assess whether Senator Bishop's comments are correct in relation to performance based pay being given secretly to people in the Public Service who, on other occasions, have been named by Ministers who have stood behind them and blamed them for errors which we believe should have been more directly sheeted home to the Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp asked first of all about extension of performance pay to SES officers. I am advised that such a system is intended to be introduced in the latter part of this year—
—We would never have guessed that from your earlier answer.
—Senator Bishop should not be like that. I said that it was not in place at the moment in relation to SES. I think the record will make that clear.

PARA.TAB: For the latter part of the year it will be introduced, but the details of that system have yet to be resolved in terms of precise guidelines that are applicable, the confirmation of the amount of money that will in fact be available to my department and others in this respect, and the internal procedures that are to apply in the distribution of that pool. So there is some distance to go before these issues are resolved, even in terms of general principles, quite apart from their application to particular individuals.

As to the general issue of principle that is involved here as to whether these payments should be regarded as appropriately subject to privacy considerations or whether there should be some overriding principle of public sector accountability applied to them, I acknowledge there is some force to the argument—if Senator Bishop would be prepared to listen, she might be interested—prima facie that accountability principles be applied here as they are indeed to other aspects of remuneration. That is a matter that could usefully be revisited by the Public Service Commission and by the Government in looking more carefully perhaps again at the weighting and balancing of the privacy consideration, which is applicable to a great many aspects of the record keeping and the determinations, the promotion procedures and so on that are applicable to particular individuals for good and obvious reasons. There is a case for looking at how one should balance out that consideration on the one hand against other accountability considerations on the other.

I acknowledge there is an argument here, and I am happy to undertake to raise that matter myself with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Public Service Commission to see again how the balance of argument falls out on mature consideration. I am able to confirm that the principle to which I referred of privacy protection for individuals in this respect does apply throughout the Public Service. That has been now confirmed; it is not something peculiar to my own department and, clearly, we have just been following other departments in that respect.

As to the business of dropping buckets on public servants, I do not think the point should pass without mention. I do not think any of us treat public servants with the kind of barely disguised contempt and ridicule that has become par for the course in terms of the behaviour of some people—Senator Bishop conspicuous among them—in the conduct of estimates committees. So do not let us have any crocodile tears at all about Ministers on occasion having to say that a mistake has been made which is attributable not to them but to public servants.

I have never heard any Minister referring publicly in this place to any public servant who may have let them down, even in some conspicuous respect, with the same kind of contempt and the same kind of disposition to ridicule that Senator Bishop routinely brings to bear to even the most unsubstantiated allegation. And let the record speak for itself in that respect.

I might also say in answer to Senator Bishop and to Senator Kemp that I do not look forward to the day when individual public servants who may have made some error along the way in the course of a year's very hard work are hauled over the coals and exposed to ridicule by the likes of Senator Bishop and others in estimates committees on the basis of the particular performance pay which they may be given. TALK.START.PARA: —Including you, sir.

—I readily concede that I make mistakes. For example, what would Senator Bishop's performance pay be like if she were revealed nakedly on the public record not to know of which country Manila was the capital? How would that stand up in the annual scrutiny of her senatorial performance. Senator Bishop would really feel quite embarrassed, I think, were her lapse in that respect to be a matter of overt public scrutiny. Senator Bishop would regard it as being extremely unfortunate if that conspicuous lack of information were to be nakedly revealed in that way.

PARA.TAB: That is the sort of situation that one could envisage arising all too frequently in the future. That is one of the policy considerations that no doubt will be relevant to any government reconsideration of this issue. So let us have no more of that sort of comment. I hope Senator Kemp will acknowledge the substantive response that I have given him. I acknowledge that some legitimate arguments of principle can be made about this, and I am happy to pursue that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up a short time of the Senate this evening to report on a conference that was held at the United Nations in New York last week which I had the privilege of attending. I would like to record some of the fundamental issues that were debated at this conference.

PARA.TAB: The conference related to the vital issue that was not debated at Rio de Janeiro during the environment debate—that is, the issue of population and development. I was able to attend the second meeting of the preparatory committee to the 1994 International Conference on Population and Development. This debate is fundamental not only to the environmental questions facing humanity, but is very much an issue that relates to more equitable distribution of resources.

At the workshop that occurred over the weekend a number of parliamentarians from 24 countries put together a declaration of the substantive issues relating to the population and development debate, and I would like to read excerpts from this declaration which was very well received by non-government organisations in particular at the conference.

It was pointed out that parliamentarians in attendance represented about 19.1 million citizens from 24 countries and all regions. The statement was made that population is the major challenge of the 1990s. The declaration states:

SPEECH.PARA: The population of the Earth is increasing by a quarter of a million each day. In the absence of wise management, the population increase will cause irreparable depletion of the planet's resources and environmental degradation, to the serious detriment of the human civilisation.

It was believed by parliamentarians attending that population and development challenges can be met, but it will require a great deal of political will and that political will will need to be demonstrated within the current decade. The document continues:

The problem is not purely one of numbers. The essential problem is the link between population size, economic growth, and the provision of services to meet the basic needs of all people. Poverty, including unemployment and appalling working conditions, results in large family size: it removes the opportunity for couples to decide for themselves. Some 95% of the population growth will occur in the developing world.

The present situation is a crisis of both human numbers and human behaviour. If human numbers are to be managed, so too must human behaviour. If the developing world must contain the expansion of its population, the developed world must contain the profligacy of its lifestyle. The richest 20 percent of the world population consume 80 percent of the resources. The underlying issues of consumption patterns in the developed world must be addressed in a meaningful way. In short, peoples of the North must eliminate over-consumption and unnecessary waste if the population and development crisis is to be resolved.
Extreme inequalities of wealth and opportunities in poor countries must also be addressed.

The subjects of population and debt took up considerable time and we were actually addressed by a representative from the World Bank. As a result, the parliamentarians at the workshop resolved as follows:We urge the World Bank, IMF and other financial institutions to ensure that structural adjustment programmes and other obligations do not damage health and education services as some have done in the past, because these are crucial to real economic and social development.

The issue of the rights and role of women was a major focus in the population and development debate. The majority of parliamentarians were women and for the first time at such a forum the numbers were quite indicative of the changing role of women in society and the increased participation of women in their parliaments.

PARA.TAB: It was resolved that progress in promoting the role of women in contemporary society is a central feature of the population and development challenge. The rights and responsibilities of women, especially in the developing world and particularly in rural areas, have been neglected and must be asserted. More attention must also be given to the rights of women to have greater economic power. Access to education for girls and women must be quickly improved, as a correlation exists between educational levels and smaller family size. Therefore, there is no better economic investment return that can be made by the international community than on education for girls, to bring them to the same level as their male counterparts.

I found it very rewarding to be part of this process of reaching a consensus on some of the difficult issues contained in the population and development debate. Of course, the fundamental issue relates to the reproductive rights of women. It was agreed that exercise of the reproductive rights of women should be recognised to ensure that women themselves—not governments—can make a choice according to individual culture and religion. The group believes that abortion must be recognised as a health issue and that, accompanied by safe, affordable and accessible contraception, fewer abortions will result. Experience shows that, when combined with better education, the provision of these services results in smaller family size through freedom of choice. With sound economic investment policies, the exercise of individual rights will significantly reduce current concern over global population trends. Governments should be challenged to combine policies of smaller family size with reduced infant and maternal mortality rates.

It was emphasised that family planning is a joint responsibility and that all countries need to focus on the education of both men and women in order to fully accept their mutual obligations as parents, including financial responsibility for children. Family planning must be integrated into community based health services with the focus on the quality of health care provided.

It was reported during the four-day discussions that a survey had been conducted by the United Nations population and development fund focusing on attitudes of women in developing countries to family size. It was found that the majority of women would have preferred not to have had their last child, and certainly did not believe that they could provide adequately for a future child. But in so many cases access to contraception, even information about contraception, was not available.

Special attention must also be given to the needs of adolescents, particularly with regard to family planning. Sex education programs must be made available, oriented to adolescents and their parents. Failure in this respect within this decade will have a major effect on fertility rates into the next century.

As to the financing of the solutions, parliamentarians believe that all OECD countries should achieve what some countries have already achieved during the 1980s—that is, the attainment of a 0.7 per cent target for official development assistance. It was also pointed out that governments should allocate four per cent of that official development assistance to population activities by the year 2000. The recent decisions by the United States in this respect are very encouraging and should be regarded by other countries as a model.

In conclusion, Silvia Hernandez from Mexico, on behalf of parliamentarians, presented this declaration to the Monday session of the conference. The following are the highlights of parliamentary commitments. First of all, parliamentarians believe that it is vitally important that they get involved in the establishment of national committees on population and development, where those committees do not yet exist, in preparation for the major Cairo conference. Of course, the Cairo conference on population will be as significant for our future as the Rio conference was last year. In Australia, while there is an interdepartmental committee that has just started work in preparation for the national report and for the Cairo conference next year, there is not yet a national committee. I hope that that position will be rectified in the near future.

Other highlights were that the provision of national reports by member countries should be reviewed by the parliament before they are submitted; the initiation of parliamentary mechanisms on population and development to ensure that national activity after the Cairo conference is maintained at the same level of political will so that recommendations from Cairo are actually implemented; the observation of World Population Day on 11 July through a variety of activities to focus the attention of governments and communities on the importance of population and development issues; parliamentarian involvement in the Cairo conference; and delegations as appropriate to Ministers of governments and institutions to involve a range of organisations, including churches, in this vital debate on our future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
